The settlement will benefit Facebook users in the US who used the platform between January 30, 2015, and April 18, 2018, and whose location data was collected despite disabling location services. Plaintiffs estimate up to 70 million claimants could be eligible for a pro rata distribution of the settlement funds.

title: NFT Licensing & Licenses - Buy a Non-Fungible Token (NFTs)
summary: This report explores the legal realities of NFT ownership, revealing that most NFTs convey zero intellectual property rights to their underlying content. It categorizes common NFT licensing agreements, highlighting discrepancies between issuer marketing and legal terms, and argues for improved frameworks for IP transfer to realize Web3's potential.

title: R|T: The Retail Times – Groupon to focus on ‘mission critical activities’ following staff cuts
summary: Groupon has cut over 500 staff and plans to focus solely on "mission-critical activities" due to underperforming business. This move is intended to improve its trajectory and generate positive cash flow by the end of 2022, following similar workforce reductions by other tech giants like Alibaba and Amazon. The article also provides updates on various other tech companies, including funding rounds, layoffs, and strategic partnerships.

title: Arista Buys Pluribus Networks To Grow Cloud Networking Offering
summary: Arista Networks has acquired Pluribus Networks to enhance its Converged Cloud Fabric offering and strengthen its partnership with Ericsson. This is Arista's second acquisition in the quarter, following Untangle, as it focuses on acquiring technology and talent that align with its culture to expand its cloud networking solutions and address lower-end security and edge threat management markets. The acquisition was disclosed as Arista reported surpassing $1 billion in quarterly revenue for the first time, despite ongoing global supply chain challenges.

title: Russian court fines Tinder owner for data law violation - RIA
summary: A Russian court has fined Match Group, the owner of the Tinder dating app, 2 million roubles ($33,280) for failing to store user data within Russia. This fine follows similar penalties imposed on Meta Platforms' WhatsApp and Snap Inc's Snapchat earlier on the same day. These actions highlight Russia's strict data localization laws affecting technology companies.

title: 3 simple ways to embed a Twitter Feed on your website
summary: This article details three methods for embedding a Twitter (now X) feed onto a website to enhance engagement and brand visibility. It covers using Twitter's own embed tool, WordPress plugins, and third-party tools like Taggbox or Flockler. The article also highlights five types of Twitter feeds that can be embedded and discusses the benefits of integrating Twitter content with a website.

title: Snap Plunges, Drags Down Social Media ETF
summary: Snap Inc. shares significantly dropped after reporting weak quarterly results due to slowing advertisement revenue, impacting the entire social media sector and the Global X Social Media ETF (SOCL). This downturn follows increased competition for ad dollars, particularly from TikTok, leading analysts to lower their recommendations and price targets for Snap. The company's struggles may reflect broader challenges within the tech and social media industries, with Snap planning reduced hiring, mirroring other major tech companies.

title: Markets Brief: Is the Bond Market a Buy Yet?
summary: Despite impending interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve, some analysts believe that long-term U.S. Treasuries are becoming an attractive investment due to increasing recession odds. While bonds have performed poorly this year, rising yields on longer-term Treasuries could reintroduce diversification benefits, especially if inflation is brought under control. Investors are urged to reconsider bonds as their valuation becomes more reasonable compared to recent years.

title: Yelp's departure is a blow for city's office market
summary: Yelp's decision to close its New York City offices and embrace a fully remote workforce is a significant blow to the city's office market, particularly for landlords in downtown Manhattan. The departure of Yelp from its 200,000 square feet at 11 Madison Square, along with other tech company retrenchments, highlights a trend of vacated spaces not being refilled, impacting the commercial real estate sector. This move reflects a broader shift by tech firms towards remote work models, leaving landlords concerned about the future of office occupancy.

title: Why Capturing Instagram Reels data is More Important than Ever...
summary: Comscore announces that Instagram Reels measurement is now live, allowing marketers and content creators to analyze their own and competitors' Reels performance. This new capability addresses a previous blind spot in social media analytics, enabling better monetization and audience reach through this rapidly growing short-form video format. Reels offer wider reach than Stories as they appear prominently in newsfeeds and the Explore section, and are not ephemeral.

title: FMET Makes It Simple to Take Long View of Metaverse
summary: The Fidelity Metaverse ETF (FMET) offers investors a way to engage with the growing metaverse theme, which is projected to be worth over $800 million by 2028. Despite a retrenchment in growth stocks, the long-term outlook for the metaverse remains compelling, especially with established companies like Meta Platforms, Alphabet, Apple, and Nvidia investing heavily in its development. FMET provides a diversified basket approach to this theme, including exposure to gaming and numerous mega-cap growth companies, with an affordable annual fee.

title: Ukraine round-up: Russia leaves Snake Island and Putin's topless G7 comments
summary: Ukraine is celebrating a significant victory as Russian troops withdrew from Snake Island after months of bombardment, though Russia claims it was a "gesture of goodwill." US intelligence agencies believe Russia still aims to take all of Ukraine, but combat has weakened their capacity, suggesting a prolonged conflict. Meanwhile, former F1 boss Bernie Ecclestone sparked controversy with pro-Putin comments, and Western leaders mocked Putin's macho image at the G7 summit.

title: Abortion assistance: Kroger to offer up to $4,000 of out-of-state travel costs for employees seeking abortion
summary: Kroger announced it will offer up to $4,000 to cover out-of-state travel costs for employees seeking abortion and fertility treatments, following the Supreme Court's decision to overturn Roe v. Wade. The company, headquartered in Cincinnati, operates stores in states like Ohio and Kentucky where abortion is now banned or mostly banned. This move aligns Kroger with nearly two dozen other major U.S. companies providing similar assistance.

title: Newmark Completes Sale of Moffett Green, Fully-Leased Trophy Campus in Silicon Valley
summary: Newmark has successfully completed the sale of Moffett Green, a 719,037 square-foot, fully-leased trophy office campus in Sunnyvale, California, to CommonWealth Partners, LLC. The transaction, which represents the largest single-asset investment office sale in Silicon Valley history, involved Meta Platforms, Inc. as the long-term tenant. Steven Golubchik and his team at Newmark facilitated the deal, highlighting continued investor demand for prime assets in high-barrier-to-entry markets and the strong performance of Moffett Park.

title: Meta class action alleges company’s platforms harm youths’ mental health
summary: A class action lawsuit has been filed against Facebook and Meta Platforms by a young woman alleging that the companies' social media platforms caused her to develop an addiction, leading to mental health issues like depression and attempted suicide. The lawsuit claims that Meta executives prioritized advertising profits over the mental well-being of young users by designing addictive algorithms, despite knowing the vulnerabilities of developing brains. This case is reportedly one of many similar lawsuits planned by the law firm Beasley Allen.

title: Mastercard Celebrates Pride Month with Your True Self is Priceless Campaign
summary: Mastercard is celebrating Pride Month with its "Your True Self is Priceless" campaign, featuring live events at New York City Pride, social media activations, and immersive metaverse experiences in Decentraland and Meta’s Horizon Worlds. The campaign encourages the LGBTQIA+ community to write letters to their younger selves, building on Mastercard's commitment to inclusivity which includes the 2019 True Name feature. Events span from sponsoring Pride Island and the NYC Pride March to offering Priceless Experiences with celebrity chefs and virtual engagements in the metaverse.

title: Is the Roundhill Ball Metaverse ETF (METV) Right for You?
summary: The Roundhill Ball Metaverse ETF (METV) offers investors diversified exposure to companies benefiting from the metaverse's growth. This article examines METV's top holdings, including Meta Platforms, Nvidia, Roblox, Microsoft, and Autodesk, highlighting their roles in the metaverse ecosystem. It also discusses the fund's expense ratio and the potential market size of the metaverse industry.

title: Meta Platforms (FB) Changes Ticker to META
summary: Meta Platforms, Inc. changed its stock ticker symbol from FB to META to align with its corporate rebranding effort, effective June 9, 2022. This change follows the company's name change from Facebook to Meta in October 2021, and shareholders are not required to take any action. The article highlights Meta's business rationale behind the rebranding, including key acquisitions that broadened its scope beyond the Facebook social media platform.

title: McDonald’s taps Workplace for crew communications
summary: McDonald's is implementing Meta's Workplace platform in its company-owned restaurants and offering it to franchisees globally as a communication and shift management tool. The platform aims to enhance employee engagement, training, and social connections among crew members. Initial pilots in Spain showed quick success in accessing information and sharing best practices, with active usage reported in various European and Asia-Pacific markets.

title: Meta Platforms to trade on Nasddaq under 'META' ticker from June 9
summary: Meta Platforms Inc. announced that its Class A common stock will begin trading on the Nasdaq under the ticker symbol 'META' starting June 9, replacing its current 'FB' ticker. This change follows the company's rebranding in October last year from Facebook Inc. to Meta Platforms Inc., which highlights its focus on building the "metaverse." The original 'FB' ticker had been in use since the company's IPO in 2012.

title: Meta Platforms, Inc. to Change Ticker Symbol to 'META' on June 9
summary: Meta Platforms, Inc. announced that its Class A common stock will begin trading under the ticker symbol 'META' on Nasdaq starting June 9, 2022, replacing its previous 'FB' symbol. This change aligns with the company's rebranding from Facebook to Meta, which was announced in October 2021. Shareholders are not required to take any action regarding this ticker symbol change.

title: Meta Platforms, Inc. to Change Ticker Symbol to 'META' on June 9
summary: Meta Platforms, Inc. announced that its Class A common stock will begin trading on NASDAQ under the new ticker symbol 'META' starting June 9, 2022. This change replaces its current 'FB' ticker, which has been in use since 2012, to align with the company's rebranding from Facebook to Meta in October 2021. Shareholders are not required to take any action, and the company's CUSIP number will remain the same.

title: Qualcomm CEO sees growth in high-end phones even if economy slows
summary: Qualcomm CEO Cristiano Amon believes the company will continue to see growth in the high-end smartphone market, despite concerns about an economic slowdown. He noted that consumers are increasingly seeking "better phones" with more capabilities, and Qualcomm is gaining market share in premium devices. Amon also highlighted the potential for augmented reality to become as significant as smartphones, expanding Qualcomm's partnerships in the AR/VR space.

title: TVA, Meta commission Tennessee's newest large-scale solar energy project
summary: TVA, Meta, and NextEra Energy Resources have commissioned the Elora Solar Energy Center, Tennessee's newest large-scale solar project. This facility will generate up to 150 megawatts of solar energy, utilizing over 500,000 photovoltaic panels. The project is expected to bring significant tax revenue to Lincoln County and supported 250 construction jobs.

title: Netflix lays off 150 employees as the streaming service contends with big subscriber losses
summary: Netflix is laying off approximately 150 employees, less than 2% of its 11,000 staffers, primarily in the U.S., due to slowing revenue growth. This move comes less than a month after the streaming service reported its first subscriber loss in a decade and saw its stock value drop significantly. The company is exploring new strategies like lower-priced, ad-supported tiers and cracking down on password sharing to regain subscribers.

title: Uber to cut costs, slow down hiring, CEO tells staff
summary: Uber Technologies Inc. will scale back hiring and reduce spending on marketing and incentives, as CEO Dara Khosrowshahi announced a shift to a leaner investment model focusing on achieving profitability on a free cash flow basis. This move comes in response to changing investor sentiment and follows similar cost-cutting measures by Meta Platforms Inc. despite Uber's robust driver base.

title: The Old Tech FAANG Is Dulled, But a New Version Has Promise
summary: Bank of America strategists have introduced "FAANG 2.0," a new grouping of sectors designed for a world facing inflation, war, and geopolitical shifts, replacing the underperforming original tech FAANG stocks. This new version, comprising fuels, aerospace and defense, agriculture, nuclear and renewables, and gold and metals/minerals, has shown significantly better market performance year to date compared to both the S&P 500 and the original tech FAANG stocks. The article highlights the rationale behind this shift, citing energy security, increased military spending, rising food prices, and gold's role as a refuge asset in the current global climate.

title: Tech sell-off pushes Nasdaq to steepest drop since June 2020
summary: A tech sell-off on Thursday, May 5, 2022 pushed the Nasdaq Composite to its steepest drop since June 2020, wiping out hundreds of billions in market value. This downturn was driven by disappointing earnings reports from cloud and e-commerce companies like Shopify, Amazon, and Meta, coupled with investor concerns following the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike to combat inflation. The rotation out of tech began in late 2021 due to inflation fears and escalated with events like Russia's invasion of Ukraine, leading to significant year-to-date losses for many "Covid winner" stocks.

title: Meta Class Action Alleges Copyright Infringement of Infinity Logo
summary: Dfinity Foundation has filed a copyright infringement class action lawsuit against Meta Platforms Inc., alleging that Meta knowingly uses a logo that infringes upon Dfinity's trademarked infinity-shaped logo. Dfinity claims that Meta's similar logo damages its reputation for protecting privacy and creates consumer confusion. The lawsuit seeks to prevent Meta from continued infringement and requests an award of all profits Meta earned from the alleged infringement.

title: Web3: It’s time to level up
summary: HSBC's Rajeev Tummala discusses Web3, defined as the read-write-own era of the internet, where users control their data and interact in virtual worlds like the metaverse. He highlights its potential applications beyond gaming in financial services, education, and entertainment, while also acknowledging challenges such as intellectual property, regulation, and data privacy. The article concludes that Web3 will likely combine both centralized and decentralized systems and that financial institutions have a crucial role to play in its evolution.

title: With interest rates rising, it's time to focus on MANG stocks instead of FAANG, according to Jefferies
summary: Jefferies analysts recommend focusing on "MANG" stocks (Microsoft, Apple, Nvidia, and Alphabet) instead of the traditional "FAANG + Microsoft" group as interest rates rise. They suggest that MANG stocks present a safer investment strategy during the Federal Reserve's monetary policy tightening. This advice was issued prior to a Federal Open Market Committee meeting.

title: Meta Platforms Sued Over Logo Infringement - ProShares S&P 500 Dynamic Buffer ETF (BATS:FB)
summary: Meta Platforms Inc. (NASDAQ: FB) is being sued by the DFINITY Foundation, the entity behind the Internet Computer (CRYPTO: ICP) blockchain, for alleged trademark infringement. DFINITY claims Meta's new infinity symbol logo, filed in March 2022, is too similar to their own, which has been in use since 2017 and trademarked since 2018. The lawsuit argues that the similarity will cause confusion among consumers due to both platforms targeting similar customer bases in the same industry.

title: MOTO & MRAD Rise on Tech Stock Rally
summary: U.S. stocks, particularly technology stocks, climbed on Thursday, with Apple and Amazon's earnings calls anticipated. Meta Platforms' strong first-quarter earnings report, showing an increase in users beyond expectations, boosted the Nasdaq Composite Index and the S&P 500 technology sector. The SmartETFs Advertising & Marketing Technology ETF (MRAD C) and the SmartETFs Smart Transportation & Technology ETF (MOTO) offer exposure to different segments of the technology sector, with MRAD focusing on advertising and marketing technology and MOTO investing in smart transportation and related tech.

title: Fidelity Enters the Metaverse with New Financial Education Experience: Invest Quest at The Fidelity Stack
summary: Fidelity Investments has launched a new gamified financial education experience called "The Fidelity Stack" in Decentraland, an eight-story virtual building designed to teach users about ETF investing through an "Invest Quest" challenge. This initiative aims to engage younger audiences, particularly the 18-35 age range, following the company's recent introduction of a metaverse-themed ETF, FMET. Fidelity views this as a significant step in providing financial education in decentralized, virtual communities.

title: Software outfit adds 152K sf, fills whole Sunnyvale office
summary: Synopsys, a software company, leased a 152,000-square-foot building in Sunnyvale for 15 years, expanding its presence in the city to four offices within walking distance. This deal deepens Synopsys’ ties to Sunnyvale, where it had almost 1,600 employees, and further tightens the city's office market which has seen significant commitments from other tech giants like Meta and LinkedIn. The lease takes a large block of vacant space off the market, with asking rents in Sunnyvale's Class A office space continuing to rise, trailing only other top Silicon Valley markets.

title: These 21 large-cap stocks have now crashed at least 50%
summary: This article highlights that 21 large-cap stocks have experienced declines of at least 50% from their 52-week highs. Notable companies mentioned include Netflix, PayPal, and Meta Platforms. The significant drops are attributed to a difficult year for technology stocks, as evidenced by major declines in broad indexes.

title: Netflix Loses $54 Billion in Market Cap After Biggest One-Day Stock Drop Ever
summary: Netflix experienced its biggest one-day stock drop ever, losing $54 billion in market capitalization after announcing its first subscriber loss in over a decade and projecting further losses. Analysts downgraded the stock, citing market saturation, increased competition, and the impact of account sharing, leading to a significant reassessment of the company's growth prospects.

title: Is Palantir Technologies Worth the Wait?
summary: Palantir Technologies (PLTR) shares are down more than 30% this year, but Morningstar analysts see an opportunity for patient investors despite the company's long history of potential with limited profits. Concerns exist regarding its multi-share-class structure, political leanings, lack of consistent GAAP profits, and a recent slowdown in government contracts. However, strong commercial revenue growth and positive free cash flow offer a more optimistic outlook for its long-term potential.

title: Li Lu Top 10 Holdings – Q4 2021, Buys FB, BAC
summary: This article details superinvestor Li Lu's top 10 holdings as of Q4 2021, derived from his 13F-HR documents. His portfolio, valued at over $2.6 billion, shows significant investments in Micron Technology, Bank of America, and Facebook, alongside other major tech companies. The report also highlights his new buys, Facebook and Bank of America, and his sell in Pinduoduo.

title: Meta Signs PPA for TransAlta 200 MW Horizon Hill Wind Project
summary: Meta has entered into a long-term renewable energy purchase agreement with TransAlta for 100% of the generation from its 200 MW Horizon Hill Wind Power Project in Oklahoma. This partnership will help Meta achieve its goal of supporting global operations with 100 percent wind and solar energy, while TransAlta expands its U.S. wind generation fleet. The project, estimated to cost between $290 million and $310 million, is expected to begin construction in Q4 2022 and achieve commercial operation by the second half of 2023.

title: ProShares Opens New Headquarters, Affirms Commitment to Greater Washington D.C. Area
summary: ProShares, a leading ETF provider, announced the opening of its new 54,000-sq.-ft. headquarters in downtown Bethesda, Maryland, reaffirming its commitment to the Greater Washington D.C. area. The move follows significant growth over the past three years, with assets under management more than doubling to over $70 billion and the launch of innovative products like the bitcoin-linked ETF (BITO). The new state-of-the-art office is designed for collaboration and positions the firm for future growth, with employees returning to in-office work.

title: MetaBank announces name change
summary: MetaBank announced its new name will be Pathward, following the sale of its existing name and trademark assets to Facebook's parent company, Meta, for $60 million in December. The full transition to Pathward, including a new brand identity and website, is expected by the end of the calendar year, with its public holding company also changing to Pathward Financial, Inc. CEO Brett Pharr stated the name change reflects the company's commitment to financial inclusion and removing barriers for the unbanked, underbanked, and underserved.

title: Facebook advertisers can pursue class action over ad rates
summary: A U.S. judge has ruled that a lawsuit accusing Meta Platforms Inc.'s Facebook of deceiving advertisers about its "potential reach" tool can proceed as a class action. This decision allows potentially millions of advertisers to sue as a group, alleging that Facebook inflated advertising reach and charged artificially high premiums for ad placements. The lawsuit claims that even senior Facebook executives were aware of the inflated metrics but took no action.

title: Financial Firm MetaBank Rebrands as Pathward
summary: MetaBank, a financial empowerment company, announced its rebranding to Pathward, unifying the company under a single identity after strategic acquisitions and a brand strategy review in 2021. The new name, Pathward, signifies the company's commitment to providing "a path forward to people and businesses" and expanding financial access for the unbanked, underbanked, and underserved. Its public holding company, Meta Financial Group, will also change its name to Pathward Financial by the end of 2022, a move further emphasized by Facebook's recent rebranding to Meta and its acquisition of Meta Financial's trademark assets.

title: Facebook Continues To Lose Out On User Time; Netherlands Data Center Plans Face Opposition
summary: Meta Platforms (NASDAQ: FB) is experiencing a decline in user engagement on Facebook, as reported by BuzzFeed CEO Jonah Peretti, which negatively impacts its commerce revenues. Concurrently, Meta's plans for a large data center in Zeewolde, Netherlands, are facing significant political opposition after the Leefbaar Zeewolde party, which campaigned against the project, won a majority in the local elections. This comes at a time when Meta is also dealing with internal pressure from employees affected by plunging stock prices.

title: The Impact of Design on the Employee Experience
summary: Workday's Chief Design Officer, Jeff Gelfuso, emphasizes the importance of delivering seamless and engaging end-to-end experiences for employees within enterprise software, mirroring consumer software expectations. He discusses how Workday is achieving this through simplification, personalization, connectedness, and data-driven insights. The article highlights key design principles and Workday's initiatives like Engage, Everywhere, and Empower to improve the employee experience.

title: ProShares Launches Metaverse ETF, Expands Innovative Fund Lineup to the Internet’s Next Frontier
summary: ProShares has launched a new Metaverse ETF (VERS) designed to offer investors access to companies at the forefront of the metaverse's發展. The ETF tracks the Solactive Metaverse Theme Index, which includes 40 companies across various industries, from device makers to social media platforms. This initiative builds on ProShares' history of product innovation, including the first bitcoin-linked ETF, and aims to capitalize on the metaverse's potential to revolutionize industries.

title: Goldman Sachs CEO Says Ostracizing Russia Isn’t the Finance Industry’s Job
summary: Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon stated that it is not the finance industry's job to ostracize Russia, but rather to follow government sanctions. He emphasized that businesses should implement policies set by the government, agreeing with the sanctions against Russia's actions in Ukraine. Despite this stance, the article highlights Goldman Sachs's historical involvement in Russia's economic policy and its mixed record on activism.

title: Metaverse Technology Redefining Digital Experience
summary: The metaverse is emerging as a significant technological advancement, moving beyond gaming to redefine digital experiences across various industries. Companies like Facebook (Meta), Nike, and Microsoft are investing heavily, with projections indicating global metaverse revenue could approach $800 billion by 2024. While offering potential for retail, enterprise solutions, and new markets like virtual real estate and entertainment, the metaverse also faces challenges related to data security, legal frameworks, skilled resources, VR device limitations, and potential negative societal impacts.

title: Biden must safeguard Russian internet access, civil society warns
summary: Civil society groups are urging the Biden administration to protect internet providers in Russia from sanctions, arguing that cutting off web access would isolate dissidents and strengthen the Kremlin's control. They recommend that the Office of Foreign Asset Controls formally authorize U.S. internet services, software, and hardware to preserve web access, citing precedents from past sanctions campaigns. The groups warn that without clear guidance, individuals in Russia could be cut off from vital internet services.

title: Goldman Sachs-Backed Virtual Beauty App Developer To Go Public In $1 Billion SPAC Deal
summary: Perfect Corp., a Taiwan-headquartered virtual beauty try-on app developer backed by Goldman Sachs, announced its plan to go public in the U.S. through a SPAC merger valued at $1 billion. The combination with Nasdaq-listed Provident Acquisition Corp. is expected to raise up to $335 million, including a $50 million PIPE investment from investors like Chanel and Shiseido. CEO Alice Chang stated the company aims to expand into Southeast Asia and the Middle East, and further integrate its augmented reality technologies across more platforms and categories, including the metaverse.

title: Tripadvisor, Google Maps Suspend Reviews of Some Russian Listings
summary: Google Maps and Tripadvisor have temporarily suspended new user reviews for certain listings in Russia, Ukraine, and Belarus. This action was taken in response to a flood of political statements posted as reviews, driven by a social media campaign urging activists to communicate with Russians via these platforms about the war in Ukraine. The companies aim to prevent the publishing of off-topic and abusive content.

title: Google, Meta face penalties in Russia as deadline passes to open local offices
summary: Google and Meta are among several internet companies facing potential penalties in Russia for failing to establish local offices and comply with a new communications law. Russia's state communications regulator, Roskomnadzor, had set a deadline of the end of February for these companies to open local offices or face restrictions. The move is part of Russia's broader effort to control internet content, with fines previously issued for failing to censor anti-government content, and recent curtailments of access to platforms like Facebook in retaliation for censoring state media.

title: How DBMS is Used by Hulu, JPMorgan Chase, and The Weather Company
summary: This article examines how Database Management Systems (DBMS) are crucial for organizations to efficiently store, retrieve, and manage data. It provides case studies of how major companies like Hulu, JPMorgan Chase, and The Weather Company leverage DBMS to address challenges, optimize operations, and maintain data integrity and security, highlighting the benefits over traditional file systems. The article demonstrates the real-world applications and positive outcomes of integrating DBMS in various industries.

title: Facebook Stops Fighting Wiretap Act Litigation After More Than a Decade
summary: Meta Platforms, Inc. (formerly Facebook) has proposed a $90 million national class action settlement in its long-running Facebook Internet Tracking Litigation, involving over 124 million Americans. The lawsuit stemmed from allegations that Facebook tracked user activity on non-Facebook sites using "Like" buttons between April 2010 and September 2011, violating federal and California Wiretap Act laws. While the settlement brings closure to a decade-long legal battle and requires deletion of old data, it also highlights potential future legal scrutiny for third-party trackers.

title: Aussie funds exposed to the Meta rout: Charts of the Week
summary: Australian managed funds and popular index-tracking ETFs, including those from Magellan, Hyperion, and Lakehouse, were significantly impacted by Meta Platforms' sharp 26% stock drop, the largest one-day market capitalization loss in US history. This "Meta rout" contributed to new year woes for growth investors, although some losses were mitigated by strong performance from Amazon.com positions within several of these funds. Sustainable funds generally avoided the Meta selloff due to ESG-related exclusions stemming from privacy concerns.

title: Amazon and Microsoft led the world in corporate purchases of clean energy in 2021
summary: Amazon and Microsoft were global leaders in corporate clean energy power purchase agreements in 2021, with Amazon holding the top spot for the second consecutive year. Combined, the two tech giants procured 12.4 GW of wind and solar power, contributing significantly to a record-setting year for corporate carbon-free energy deals. Both companies are committed to achieving 100% renewable energy for their operations by 2025, with Microsoft aiming for 24/7 clean energy by 2030.

title: Morgan Stanley Sees $8 Trillion Metaverse Market — In China Alone
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts an $8 trillion metaverse market in China alone, replacing the mobile internet with a more "immersive experience." The investment bank acknowledges significant technological and regulatory hurdles for mass adoption, estimating an initial total addressable market of $4 trillion before expanding to $8 trillion as it disrupts offline activities.

title: Timing Is Everything For ETFs
summary: Thematic ETFs, which invest in specific market themes, have grown significantly. Their success often depends heavily on the timing of their launch, sometimes due to unintentional events, as exemplified by the ETFMG Prime Cyber Security ETF (HACK) benefiting from major cybersecurity breaches shortly after its inception. Conversely, funds like the Sprott Buzz Social Media Insights ETF (BUZ) failed due to poor timing, while later similar entrants thrived by tapping into peak market interest.

title: The 3 Best Carbon Stocks of 2022
summary: This article highlights the top three carbon-related investment opportunities for 2022, emphasizing the growing importance of carbon markets and green investing. It details the KraneShares Global Carbon Strategy ETF (KRBN) for broad market exposure, Carbon Streaming Corporation (NETZ/OFSTF) as an early mover in carbon credit streaming, and Brookfield Renewable Partners (BEP) for a more conservative renewable energy play. The article underscores how increasing net-zero ambitions among corporations and rising awareness of climate change will drive investor interest in these sectors.

title: A Guide to Investing in Emerging Asian Markets Outside of China
summary: This article discusses investment opportunities in five emerging Asian markets—Pakistan, Bangladesh, Indonesia, Vietnam, and the Philippines—dubbed "Asian Growth Cubs" by Dawn Global Management. These countries offer significant growth potential for investors looking for exposure to Asian markets outside of China and India, with a collective GDP similar to India's but a much lower market cap. The article highlights the Asian Growth Cubs ETF (CUBS) as a way for foreign investors to access these markets, focusing on industries like healthcare, telecom, and technology.

title: Facebook faces $3.2 bln UK class action over market dominance
summary: Facebook, now Meta Platforms, is facing a £2.3 billion ($3.2 billion) class-action lawsuit in the UK for allegedly abusing its market dominance by exploiting the personal data of 44 million users between 2015 and 2019. The lawsuit, brought by Liza Lovdahl Gormsen, claims Facebook imposed unfair terms requiring users to surrender valuable personal data to access its network. This legal challenge comes shortly after Facebook lost an attempt to strike out an antitrust lawsuit from the Federal Trade Commission in the U.S.

title: Tech Moves: Adaptive CFO to resign; Meta comms exec departs; AI vet joins Absci board; new Zymeworks CEO
summary: This article details several significant personnel changes in the tech and biotech sectors, including Chad Cohen's resignation as CFO of Adaptive Biotechnologies, Joseph Sirosh's appointment to the Absci board, John Pinette's departure from Meta, and Kenneth Galbraith becoming the new CEO of Zymeworks. It highlights the impact of these moves on the respective companies and their financial performance or strategic direction.

title: What Crypto-related ETFs Could Hit the US Market in 2022?
summary: The article discusses the potential for various crypto-related ETFs, particularly metaverse products, to launch in the US market in 2022, while the approval of spot bitcoin and ether futures products remains uncertain. Industry experts express apprehension about the immediate investability of metaverse ETFs due to potential crossover in holdings and a lack of pure-play names. There's also skepticism regarding the SEC's approval of a spot bitcoin ETF in 2022, with some analysts expecting an ether futures-based ETF to gain approval sooner.

title: Social Media Company Quora Is Going Public: Here Are the Details
summary: Quora is considering going public, potentially following other social media companies like Reddit, Rumble, and TMTG. While no IPO date has been set, Reuters reported Quora could go public in 2022 with a valuation of $4 billion, a significant increase from its 2019 private funding. The company generates revenue through advertising and subscription products, aiming to become free-cash-flow-positive on ad revenue alone.

title: Boeing Wants to Build its Next Airplane in the 'Metaverse'
authors: VOA - Voice of America English News
summary: Boeing plans to revolutionize its aircraft manufacturing by uniting design, production, and services under a single digital system, aiming to build its next airplane in the "metaverse" within the next two years. This digital transformation, involving 3-D designs, robots, and mixed reality headsets, seeks to improve quality, safety, and efficiency while reducing design-related issues. The initiative also comes as the company tries to regain trust after the 737 MAX crisis and avoid future manufacturing problems like those encountered with the 787 Dreamliner.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: Equinix acquires MainOne to enter African data center market
summary: Equinix, the world’s largest data center company, has acquired MainOne for $320 million, marking its entry into the African data center market. This strategic move aims to provide "continental edge" data center services in Africa, leveraging MainOne's extensive network infrastructure, including a 7k km submarine cable and over 1.2k km of terrestrial fiber. The acquisition is expected to close in Q1 2022 and will see MainOne's founder and over 500 employees join Equinix, enabling faster scaling and broader international customer reach.

title: Meta now listed as Facebook developer on Google Play and App Store
summary: Following Facebook's rebrand to Meta earlier this year, the company's Android and iOS apps, such as Messenger, now list "Meta Platforms, Inc." as the developer. This change applies primarily to apps directly associated with the Facebook name, while Instagram and WhatsApp still list their respective company names as developers. The update reflects the corporation's new identity but does not alter the user experience.

title: Focus: Boeing wants to build its next airplane in the 'metaverse'
authors: Eric M. Johnson and Tim Hepher
summary: Boeing is launching an ambitious strategy to integrate a digital ecosystem for designing, producing, and servicing its aircraft, utilizing technologies like immersive 3-D engineering and HoloLens headsets. This "metaverse" approach aims to improve quality, safety, and efficiency, preventing issues like those encountered with the 737 MAX and 787 Dreamliner. While facing challenges and skepticism due to past technological hurdles and R&D cuts, Boeing believes this digital transformation is crucial for its future aircraft programs and competitive edge against rivals like Airbus.

title: Facebook exposes mercenary spy firms that targeted 50,000 people
summary: Meta Platforms Inc (FB.O) has exposed half a dozen mercenary spy firms for targeting approximately 50,000 people across its platforms through hacking and other abuses. This crackdown involved suspending 1,500 accounts and signals a broader push by tech companies and the U.S. government against digital espionage services. The firms, including Black Cube and BellTroX, were accused of various tactics from creating fake profiles to phishing attacks.

title: Meta, CBSE tie-up: ‘Opportunity to invest in entrepreneurial spirit,’ says Mark Zuckerberg
summary: Mark Zuckerberg announced an expanded collaboration between Meta and CBSE to train 10 lakh teachers and over a crore students in virtual and augmented reality over the next three years. This partnership aims to invest in the entrepreneurial spirit and integrate Metaverse tools and training into India's education system. Meta will also provide a curriculum on digital safety, online well-being, VR, and AR available on CBSE's website.

title: The Invesco QQQ Stock Price Is Up 23.7% Since January. Could There Be More Gains?
summary: The Invesco QQQ Trust (NASDAQ: QQQ) has seen its stock price rise 23.7% since January, driven by major tech companies like Apple and Google, despite recent pullbacks. Investors are closely watching the Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting for potential hawkish policies that could further impact the Nasdaq index and the QQQ ETF. While the ETF is currently in a downtrend, its present stock price may be attractive for a future rally, though a clear upward trend based on EMA crossings is yet to materialize.

title: What Zoom’s $85m class action lawsuit means for data privacy
summary: Zoom has agreed to pay an $85 million settlement in a class action lawsuit alleging it shared user data without consent and falsely claimed end-to-end encryption. This case highlights a broader data privacy movement forcing companies to increase transparency and adjust to stricter regulations. Experts believe the lawsuit serves as a cautionary tale for the digital ecosystem and will prompt other companies to re-evaluate their data protection policies.

title: Jayhawk Wind Farm in Kansas Commences Commercial Operations
summary: WEC Energy Group's 190 MW Jayhawk Wind Farm in Kansas has begun commercial operations, selling energy to Meta under a long-term contract. WEC Energy Group invested an estimated $302 million for a 90% ownership stake and tax benefits, aligning with its ESG Progress Plan. Invenergy acquired the remaining 10% and will operate the facility, which was developed by Apex Clean Energy.

title: Go With GINN as High-Margin Companies Remain Trendy
summary: Investors are expected to favor quality, high-margin companies in 2022, a trend supported by the Goldman Sachs Innovate Equity ETF (GINN). GINN tracks companies with robust profitability, strong earnings growth, and effective margin management, aligning with Goldman Sachs' recommendation for clients. Several of GINN's holdings, including Alphabet, Meta Platforms, Apple, Marvell Technology, Mastercard, PayPal, Autodesk, and Etsy, are featured on Goldman's list of high-margin companies.

title: How new office may help Meta widen presence, rebuild image
summary: Meta Platforms Inc. inaugurated its first standalone office in Asia, located in Gurgaon, to house teams for Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp. This move is aimed at widening its presence in India, its largest market by users, and rebuilding its image after facing global allegations regarding hate-speech and inadequate local language investment. The new office includes a Centre for Fuelling India’s New Economy (CFINE) designed to train small businesses, entrepreneurs, and creators.

title: Adobe buys social media marketing startup ContentCal
summary: Adobe Inc. has acquired ContentCal, a six-year-old social media marketing startup, for an undisclosed sum reported to be over $100 million. ContentCal’s platform helps businesses manage social marketing planning and processes, offering tools for collaboration, scheduling, and performance tracking. This acquisition is expected to enhance Adobe's creative tools with expanded social media capabilities, following its earlier purchase of Frame.io Inc.

title: Rohingya refugees sue Facebook for $150 billion over Myanmar violence
summary: Rohingya refugees are suing Meta Platforms Inc (formerly Facebook) for $150 billion, alleging the company failed to address anti-Rohingya hate speech on its platform that contributed to violence in Myanmar. Both a U.S. class-action complaint and a letter of notice in the UK have been filed, citing Facebook's inaction and platform design as factors enabling real-world harm. The lawsuit also references previous UN investigations, Reuters reports, and whistleblower claims regarding Facebook's inadequate policing of abusive content in vulnerable countries.

title: Rohingya refugees from Myanmar sue Facebook for $150B for spreading hate speech
summary: Rohingya refugees from Myanmar are suing Meta Platforms Inc (formerly Facebook) for $150 billion, alleging the social media company failed to act against anti-Rohingya hate speech that contributed to real-world violence. A class-action lawsuit filed in California and a letter of notice in London claim Facebook's content policing failures and platform design fueled the atrocities. Legal experts note the challenge of applying foreign law in U.S. courts due to Section 230 protections, which shield platforms from liability for user-posted content.

title: The metaverse needs aggressive regulation
summary: The author, a pioneer in AR/VR technology, argues for aggressive regulation of the metaverse to prevent large corporations from extensive monitoring and manipulation of users. He emphasizes the need to restrict data collection, regulate real-time marketing tactics, and ensure transparency regarding AI-controlled agents and targeted placements. The article warns that without regulation, the metaverse risks becoming an environment where powerful entities exploit user data and emotions for commercial gain.

title: Meta leases former NetApp HQ in biggest U.S. real estate deal of 2021
summary: Social media giant Meta has leased a more than 700,000-square-foot campus in Sunnyvale, which was formerly NetApp's headquarters. This deal marks the biggest U.S. real estate transaction of 2021. NetApp had been selling off its properties in Sunnyvale since 2016, completing the sale of its final pieces in 2021.

title: Meta Directed to Sell Giphy; WPP Acquires Cloud Commerce Group
summary: Meta has been directed by the UK Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) to sell Giphy, following concerns that the acquisition would reduce competition among social media platforms and in the display advertising market. Separately, WPP announced its acquisition of e-commerce technology provider Cloud Commerce Group as part of its strategy to bolster its commerce and technology units. Additionally, Algerian on-demand services provider Yassir raised USD$30m in Series A funding to develop a super-app for the MENA region, focusing on financial inclusion.

title: Meta Selects AWS as Key, Long-Term Strategic Cloud Provider
summary: Meta has deepened its relationship with Amazon Web Services (AWS) as a strategic cloud provider, leveraging AWS's infrastructure for research and development, third-party collaborations, and operational efficiency. The companies will also work together to optimize PyTorch performance on AWS, facilitating faster and easier development, training, deploying, and operating of AI/ML models for enterprises. This collaboration aims to help organizations bring large-scale deep learning models from research to production more efficiently on AWS.

title: Facebook parent grabs another 1M sf in Bay Area
summary: Meta (Facebook's parent company) has leased an additional 1 million square feet of office space in the Bay Area, specifically in Sunnyvale and Burlingame, to reduce employee commute times and support its net-zero carbon emission goal. The lease of four buildings in Sunnyvale, totaling over 700,000 square feet, is considered the largest private-sector office lease in the U.S. this year. This expansion further solidifies Sunnyvale's position as a key office market in Silicon Valley.

title: Bret Taylor appointed co-CEO of Salesforce as shares drop on lower-than-expected forcecast
summary: Bret Taylor has been appointed co-chief executive officer of Salesforce Inc. The announcement came the same day Salesforce's shares dropped in after-hours trading due to a lower-than-expected earnings forecast. Despite better-than-expected Q3 results of $1.27 a share profit and $6.86 billion in revenue, investors reacted negatively to Q4 guidance that projected lower profits than analysts anticipated.

title: Meta Postpones Ticker Symbol Change to Q1 2022
summary: Meta Platforms, Inc. announced a postponement of its Class A common stock ticker symbol change until Q1 2022. The company previously intended for the change to be effective on December 1, 2021. In the interim, Meta's Class A common stock will continue to trade on NASDAQ under the ticker symbol 'FB'.

title: Apple sues company known for hacking iPhones on behalf of governments
summary: Apple has filed a lawsuit against NSO Group, an Israeli firm that develops software to hack iPhones, alleging that the company weaponizes powerful state-sponsored spyware against innocent users. Apple seeks a permanent injunction to prevent NSO Group from using its software, services, or devices and is seeking damages exceeding $75,000. Additionally, Apple will donate $10 million and any lawsuit damages to organizations combating digital surveillance, while also pledging to inform iPhone users targeted by Pegasus malware.

title: Luxury NFT Market Could Hit $56B by 2030: Morgan Stanley
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts that the luxury market could generate $56 billion in revenue by 2030 from metaverse gaming and non-fungible tokens (NFTs). The report highlights that NFTs and social gaming offer significant opportunities for luxury brands to monetize their intellectual property. The total NFT market is projected to grow to around $300 billion by 2030, with luxury brands potentially expanding their total addressable market by over 10% and industry earnings by approximately 25%.

title: Qualcomm forecasts post-Apple sales growth, shares hit all-time high
summary: Qualcomm Inc. expects its chip sales to Apple Inc. to significantly decrease in the coming years as Apple develops its own modem chips. However, Qualcomm anticipates robust growth in other sectors like autonomous cars, the internet of things, and virtual reality headsets, which led to its shares hitting a record high. The company projects substantial revenue increases from automotive and IoT divisions, offsetting the expected decline from Apple.

title: Ohio PERS sues Facebook over alleged misrepresentations
summary: The Ohio Public Employees’ Retirement System has filed a securities class-action lawsuit against Meta Platforms Inc. (formerly Facebook) and its executive officers, including CEO Mark Zuckerberg. The lawsuit alleges misrepresentations made by the social media giant. This action comes amidst other financial news concerning private credit, university endowments, and pension funds.

title: Podcast: Rivian's blockbuster IPO is a triumph of entrepreneurship
summary: This podcast episode discusses Rivian's blockbuster $12 billion IPO, highlighting it as a significant entrepreneurial achievement. It also touches on whether a deal with Meta could help AMD compete more effectively with Intel. The article celebrates Rivian's success and explores potential shifts in the tech industry.

title: Facebook Is Under Fire, but It's Also Undervalued
summary: Despite ongoing controversies, regulatory scrutiny, and a company name change to Meta Platforms, Morningstar's analysis suggests that the stock is undervalued, trading at a 16% discount to its fair value estimate. The article highlights Meta's two business segments—its legacy apps and the new Reality Labs for metaverse development—and discusses the potential impacts of regulatory and antitrust risks, concluding that the stock remains the most attractive social-media play in Morningstar's coverage. The company's revenue growth is primarily driven by advertising, leveraging its vast user base and the shift towards online spending, while its wide economic moat is based on network effects and intangible data assets.

title: Meta Stitches Cisco, Arista to Open Compute Project Switches
summary: Meta has integrated Cisco and Arista Networks into its Open Compute Project (OCP) efforts by announcing new top-of-rack switches and improvements to its data center fabrics. This expansion includes the introduction of the OCP Switch Abstraction Interface (SAI) to standardize APIs for network hardware. Meta also shared future goals, including an open die-to-die interface and a commitment to net-zero emissions by 2030.

title: AMD lands Meta as customer and takes on Nvidia, sending shares up 11%
summary: Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) shares rose 11% after announcing Meta Platforms Inc. as a new data center chip customer, intensifying its competition with Intel. AMD also unveiled new chips, including the MI200 for AI and machine learning to challenge Nvidia, and the Bergamo processor for cloud computing to compete with Ampere Computing. These strategic moves bolster AMD's market position against larger rivals and secure its presence with major cloud providers.

title: AMD shares close up 10% after company wins Meta partnership, announces new chips
summary: AMD shares surged 10% after the company announced a partnership with Meta (formerly Facebook) as a chip customer and unveiled a new range of chips at its Accelerated Data Center Premiere event. This move strengthens AMD's position against competitors like Intel, as the company continues to gain market share with its data center chip sales experiencing significant growth. Additional details about the Meta partnership are expected to be revealed later in the week at the Open Compute Project summit.

title: EXPLAINED: What is Metaverse and Why Facebook/ Meta Thinks it's the Future of Internet
summary: This article explains the concept of the metaverse, why Facebook (now Meta) views it as the future of the internet, and what its potential applications are. It details how the metaverse would work, from virtual interactions and business opportunities to the technologies being developed to build it, while also touching on data privacy concerns.

title: How To Target Your Audience Without Third-Party Cookie Data
summary: This article explores the impending demise of third-party cookies by late 2023 and its implications for digital advertising. It discusses how advertisers will face challenges in targeting ads and measuring performance, and outlines three potential scenarios for digital ad targeting: walled gardens, a consent economy, and identity innovation. The article also provides strategies for marketers to adapt, focusing on first-party data, direct publisher relationships, and contextual advertising.

title: Investing in Mark Zuckerberg’s vision of the Metaverse with an ETF
summary: This article discusses investing in Mark Zuckerberg's vision of the Metaverse following Facebook's rebranding to Meta. It explains what the Metaverse is, how investors can gain exposure through companies involved in its creation like Roblox and Unity Software, and highlights the Roundhill Ball Metaverse ETF (NYSE:META) which tracks a basket of such stocks. The article also provides information on thematic ETFs and the fund manager, Roundhill Investments.

title: As pandemic home life eases, EA should reach into the Metaverse
summary: Analysts suggest that as pandemic home life eases, Electronic Arts Inc. should develop a metaverse strategy around its popular game titles to keep players engaged and drive further monetization. This move is seen as crucial for video game publishers to stay relevant in the long haul, especially as the global metaverse market is projected to grow significantly. EA is currently reviewing its naming rights agreement with FIFA and faces competition from rivals like Roblox and Epic Games' Fortnite, which already incorporate metaverse elements.

title: Facebook will shut down facial recognition system
summary: Facebook announced it is shutting down its facial recognition system due to growing societal concerns and regulatory uncertainty regarding the technology's use. This move will delete the facial recognition templates of over 1 billion people and comes amid increased scrutiny on the tech industry's ethical use of such systems. While privacy groups welcome the decision, Facebook has not ruled out using facial recognition in other limited use cases like identity verification.

title: Facebook Announces Corporate Name Change to Meta
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced the company's corporate name change to Meta Platforms Inc., aligning with its focus on developing the metaverse. The rebrand positions the company as a computing platform, moving beyond its social media-first identity, despite ongoing controversies surrounding data privacy and content moderation. The company's main social media apps will retain their names, and its stock will trade under the new ticker MVRS starting December 1st.

title: Facebook’s reported name change reinforces its image as the new Big Tobacco
summary: Facebook is reportedly planning to rebrand itself with a new name, drawing comparisons to Philip Morris's name change to Altria Group two decades ago. Critics argue that a new brand name won't solve Facebook's fundamental problems, such as the negative effects of its platforms and its tendency to prioritize profit over public health, echoing sentiments that Big Tobacco used rebranding to distract from harmful practices. Experts suggest that for the rebrand to be successful, it needs to be accompanied by a genuine internal change in culture, values, and vision, rather than just a superficial PR move.

title: Trump wants his media company to rival Twitter, Netflix and Amazon
summary: Former President Donald Trump announced the launch of Trump Media & Technology Group (TMTG), aiming to create a media network that rivals Big Tech platforms like Twitter, Netflix, and Amazon. The company plans to launch a social media site called TRUTH Social, develop a subscription video-on-demand service (TMTG+), and build internet technology infrastructure. This initiative comes after Trump's bans from major social media platforms and saw TMTG's stock surge over 350% on its debut through a merger with Digital World Acquisition Corp.

title: Facebook Changes and Second Whistleblower, Comcast’s Spam Call Feature, AT&T Picks Ericsson for 5G
summary: Facebook is implementing changes to protect teens from harmful content on Instagram and is facing a second whistleblower. Comcast has launched a new spam call blocking feature for its Xfinity Voice customers, allowing them to manage unwanted calls. AT&T has partnered with Ericsson in a five-year deal to build out its standalone 5G network using C-band spectrum, aiming to cover a significant portion of the U.S. population by the end of 2023.

title: Amazon's Twitch blames configuration error for data breach
summary: Amazon's Twitch has attributed a recent data breach to an error in a server configuration change, which allowed an alleged hacker to leak sensitive information. The platform is still assessing the full impact but has reset all stream keys, while assuring users that login credentials and full credit card details were not exposed. This incident follows a similar "faulty configuration change" that caused a widespread outage for Facebook Inc.

title: WhatsApp, Facebook, Instagram back online after hours of outage
summary: WhatsApp, Facebook, and Instagram were restored after a widespread global outage. The outage, which affected millions of users, caused Facebook shares to fall significantly and led to apologies from the companies involved. The article also mentions previous outages and the potential cause related to DNS errors.

title: INSIGHTS | Conservative investors are pairing portfolio with principles
summary: Tom Carter, a mutual fund executive, has launched the American Conservative Values ETF to allow conservative investors to align their portfolios with their principles, avoiding "woke" companies. The fund, which began in October and already manages over $28 million, aims to provide an option for individuals who wish to invest in companies that share their conservative values rather than those that engage in social and racial justice advocacy. This initiative reflects a broader movement where conservatives are using economic choices to "fight back" against companies perceived as aligning with liberal politics.

title: Apple threatened Facebook ban over slavery posts on Instagram
summary: Apple threatened to remove Facebook's products from its App Store in 2019 after a BBC investigation revealed domestic "slaves" were being sold on apps, including Instagram. The Wall Street Journal's "Facebook Files" revealed Facebook took limited action until Apple's threat, despite internal reports showing knowledge of the online slave trade prior to the BBC's inquiry. Following the BBC report and Apple's intervention, Facebook banned hashtags, removed accounts, and developed technology to proactively address content related to domestic servitude.

title: Disney Is Harnessing The Power Of Influencers With Its ‘Disney Creators Lab’
summary: The Walt Disney Company has launched the 'Disney Creators Lab,' an initiative to guide and train 20 existing social media influencers who promote its brand. This program aims to create a more efficient system for integrating creators into Disney's marketing efforts, offering them online courses on branding, merchandising, and content monetization. While Disney does not directly pay participants, the influencers gain skills that can lead to future financial revenue through brand sponsorships.

title: Emerson is back in court after judge rejects $77m BladeRoom trade secrets ruling
summary: Emerson Electric has won a new chance to dispute allegations of stealing trade secrets from UK company BladeRoom to build a data center for Facebook, after a previous $77 million ruling was vacated. The 9th US Circuit Court of Appeals found that the district court had misinterpreted a non-disclosure agreement between BladeRoom and Emerson, preventing Emerson from presenting its full defense. The case, which involves allegations of intellectual property theft related to modular data center designs for Facebook's Luleå data center, will now return to court for a new trial.

title: Will Facebook Stock Ever Split? (NASDAQ:FB)
summary: This article discusses the potential for a stock split for Facebook (FB), noting its attractive growth and valuation. The author suggests that while a stock split could be beneficial for factors like index inclusion, investors should not base their buying decisions solely on this possibility. Facebook is presented as an attractive investment with or without a stock split.

title: Class Action Claims Facebook Advertising Platform Allows Scammers to Thrive [UPDATE]
summary: A class action lawsuit alleges that Facebook's advertising platform actively facilitates and encourages scammers to target users with deceptive ads, prioritizing revenue over user safety. An update notes that the initial lawsuit was dismissed with leave to amend, as the judge found Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act immunized Facebook from liability, unless it could be proven Facebook actively developed the illegal ad content. The lawsuit highlights Facebook's alleged involvement at industry conferences attended by known scammers and its turning a blind eye to policy violations from high-paying advertisers, particularly those based in China.

title: Unity buys remote desktop streaming app Parsec for $320M, its biggest acquisition yet
summary: Unity Software Inc. is acquiring remote desktop provider Parsec Cloud Inc. for $320 million, marking its largest acquisition to date. This move underscores Unity's ambition to expand beyond video game development and attract more creators to its platform, leveraging Parsec's remote desktop streamlining capabilities for real-time 3D experiences. The acquisition coincides with Unity reporting strong second-quarter financial results, beating Wall Street's expectations with a 48% increase in revenue year-over-year.

title: Klarna acquires platform that connects content creators, retailers
summary: Klarna announced its acquisition of Apprl, a platform connecting content creators and retailers, to expand its retail marketing services. This move allows Klarna's partners to collaborate with creators on shoppable content and measure campaign results, aiming to enrich the shopping experience and accelerate retailer growth. The acquisition follows other strategic moves by Klarna, highlighting its entry into social commerce alongside other major companies.

title: The Walt Disney Co. Will Require That Salaried And Non-Union Hourly Employees In U.S. Be Vaccinated
summary: The Walt Disney Co. has announced a new requirement for all salaried and non-union hourly employees in the U.S. to be fully vaccinated against COVID-19. Unvaccinated employees working on site will have 60 days to comply, while new hires will need to be fully vaccinated before starting employment. The company is also discussing the mandate with unions representing its collectively bargained workers, citing health and safety as a top priority.

title: How an Investor Helped Netflix Disclose Its ESG Performance
summary: Individual investor Lily Bowles successfully prompted Netflix to disclose its material ESG performance through a shareholder resolution, which she later withdrew after the company demonstrated willingness to comply. Her experience highlights how difficult it is for individual investors to engage with companies, especially with new SEC restrictions that make such efforts harder to replicate despite the potential for positive change. The article also discusses the potential for rule changes under the new SEC chairperson to mitigate these challenges.

title: Will DaVita’s indictment alter its big political spending in California?
summary: Dialysis giant DaVita and its former CEO face federal antitrust charges, raising questions about the company's substantial political spending in California. DaVita spent $135 million to defeat two ballot measures and contributed $1.3 million to state politicians, making it a major player in California politics. The indictment, while unrelated to patient treatment, could impact lawmakers' willingness to accept contributions from the company.

title: News Corp. closes Knewz aggregator site
summary: News Corp. has shut down its news aggregation service, Knewz, just 18 months after its launch. The platform, which aimed to offer diverse news content as an alternative to Google and Facebook, cited a lack of profitability as the reason for its closure despite attracting millions of users. News Corp. stated that Knewz served as an important proving ground for technology that will continue to benefit its other businesses.

title: Billionaire investor Peter Thiel has $5B in his tax-free retirement account, report finds
summary: A ProPublica report alleges that billionaire investor Peter Thiel grew his Roth IRA to $5 billion, largely tax-free, by investing early shares of PayPal and Facebook. This practice, while legal, raises questions about the effectiveness and fairness of the current tax system, according to tax experts and lawmakers. The report highlights how the wealthy can use retirement accounts, intended for middle-class savings, to accumulate vast, tax-exempt fortunes from capital gains.

title: New research shows social media has created a more
summary: New research from Sprout Social indicates that social media has intensified competition for brands, with 93% of marketers agreeing, but also serves as a critical tool for differentiation and staying ahead. The 2021 Sprout Social Index: Accelerate highlights that 90% of marketers rely on social data to gain a competitive edge, though few fully leverage this data for ROI measurement or business decisions. The study also reveals that while consumers expect strong customer service on social, marketers often deprioritize it, missing opportunities for engagement and bottom-line growth.

title: Six Flags Great America season pass holders could get up to $200 each in $36 million class-action privacy settlement
summary: Six Flags Great America has agreed to a $36 million settlement in a class-action privacy lawsuit concerning the use of fingerprint scanners. Season pass holders and members who visited the park between October 1, 2013, and December 31, 2018, could receive up to $200 each. The lawsuit stemmed from alleged violations of Illinois' biometric privacy law, which does not require proof of actual injury for a claim to proceed.

title: Vornado nabs Empire Health as tenant for Penn 1 office tower
summary: Vornado Realty Trust has secured a new 70,000-square-foot lease at its Penn 1 office tower with Empire Health Choice, which is relocating from downtown. This deal is part of a larger $450 million capital improvement program for Penn 1, including extensive "WorkLife" amenities. The lease marks a significant win for Vornado's Phase I redevelopment efforts around Penn Station.

title: I'm Not Turning Off App Tracking On My iPhone, Because I’m A Total Cuck
summary: The author humorously explains her decision to not disable app tracking on her iPhone, despite Apple's new privacy feature allowing users to opt out. She describes herself as a "datacuck" who enjoys personalized ads and wants to see "how far this goes" when it comes to data collection, contrasting her personal choice with the recommended smart privacy practices. The article satirically delves into the perceived benefits of targeted advertising while acknowledging the serious implications of data privacy and Facebook's track record.

title: Looking for an ETF to Hold for the Long-Term?
summary: The article suggests the Schwab U.S. Large-Cap Growth ETF (SCHG) as a long-term investment option, highlighting its strong performance and holdings in major growth companies. It emphasizes the potential for significant long-term returns through consistent investing in such ETFs, despite the allure of instant gratification.

title: Google (GOOGL) stock hits all-time high on Q1 2021 earnings, announces $50 billion buyback
summary: Alphabet (Google's parent company) reported record Q1 2021 earnings, with revenues of $55.31 billion and EPS of $26.29, significantly beating analyst estimates. Google's stock hit an all-time high of over $2400/share in after-hours trading following the announcement. The company also announced a new $50 billion share repurchase program for its Class C capital stock.

title: What do Apple’s new privacy settings mean for you?
summary: Apple is rolling out new privacy settings requiring app developers to explicitly ask users for permission to track their browsing habits across other apps and websites. This change is expected to significantly impact the mobile advertising market as many users are anticipated to decline tracking, potentially reducing ad effectiveness and revenue for businesses and publishers. The move has created a rift with companies like Facebook, which argues it will harm small businesses.

title: Apple and Google Are Killing the (Ad) Cookie. Here’s Why
summary: Apple and Google are implementing separate changes that will effectively end the use of third-party advertising cookies, significantly altering how marketers track online activity and target ads. Apple is requiring app developers to gain user permission for tracking across apps and websites, while Google is developing a cookie alternative that allows for targeted advertising without relying on individual web history. Both tech giants cite privacy as the driving force behind these changes, though Google also emphasizes balancing privacy with the financial viability of web publishing.

title: The ARKW ETF: Leading the Future of Advertising
summary: The ARK Web x.0 ETF (ARKW) is an actively managed ETF focused on disruptive growth and internet-driven themes, including internet advertising. The article highlights ARKW's leverage to the increasing shift towards digital advertising, particularly as retail footprints decline. It projects significant growth in US digital ad spending, suggesting its critical role in the future economy.

title: Swvl’s co-founder and former CTO Ahmed Sabbah launches Telda, a Venmo-like app for Gen Z in Egypt
summary: Ahmed Sabbah, co-founder and former CTO of Swvl, has launched Telda, a fintech app aimed at Gen Z in Egypt, similar to Venmo. Telda offers digital accounts with a free Mastercard-powered card for online and in-store payments, cash withdrawals, and facilitates easy money transfers between users. The app has partnered with a local bank to operate in Egypt and plans to expand to Saudi Arabia soon.

title: As Ad Spending Explodes, Look to These Communications ETFs
summary: The U.S. advertising market is projected to grow significantly in 2021 as businesses increase spending to recover from the pandemic, with an anticipated 15% expansion excluding political advertising. This resurgence is driven by stimulus measures and economic recovery, particularly benefiting digital ad platforms like Facebook and Google. Investors can capitalize on this trend through communication services ETFs such as XLC, FCOM, and VOX, which include major players in the digital advertising space.

title: Technology and the Free Press: The Need for Healthy Journalism in a Healthy Democracy
summary: This article by Brad Smith, Vice Chair & President of Microsoft, discusses the critical relationship between technology and a healthy free press in a democracy. It highlights how technology, particularly the dominance of companies like Google in digital advertising and content aggregation, has negatively impacted the financial viability of journalism, especially local news. Smith advocates for a multi-faceted solution involving continued evolution within journalism, greater responsibility from tech companies, and government intervention through legislation modeled after Australia's recent law to restore competition and support news organizations.

title: You’ve Got a Friend in New Social-Media Apps - WSJ
summary: Dating apps are evolving to focus on platonic friendships, addressing an unmet need for connecting with new people. This shift comes as traditional social media platforms for existing friends are saturated, suggesting a new niche in the social networking market. Bumble BFF, launched in 2016, is an example of this trend.

title: Here’s how the FAANG companies stack up this earnings season
summary: The article discusses the strong performance of FAANG companies during the earnings season, specifically highlighting their impressive revenue growth and pricing power. This trend continued into the fourth quarter of the previous year and throughout the entire year, even amidst the pandemic. The author notes that these companies consistently deliver significant increases in revenue despite their large size.

title: Here’s how the FAANG companies stack up this earnings season
summary: This article examines the performance of FAANG companies during the latest earnings season, highlighting their continued impressive growth in revenue and display of pricing power. Despite their large size and the challenges posed by the pandemic, these companies maintained successful growth strategies in the fourth quarter and throughout the previous year. The piece underscores the dominance of FAANG stocks in earnings reports.

title: Apple, Its Control Over the iPhone, and The Internet
summary: This article examines Apple's extensive control over the iPhone ecosystem and its implications for the internet, competition, and future digital economies. It argues that Apple's policies, while leading to success, inhibit innovation and create anti-competitive barriers for developers and users through its App Store, payment systems, and technology decisions. The author suggests regulatory intervention to force competition in app distribution and payments, allowing users to download apps from any source and developers to use alternative payment solutions.

title: T. Rowe Price Blue Chip Growth's Manager to Retire
summary: Larry Puglia, the long-standing manager of T. Rowe Price Blue Chip Growth (TRBCX) since its inception in 1993, is set to retire at the end of 2021. Paul Greene, who became associate portfolio manager in January 2020, will officially take over on October 1, 2021, ensuring a smooth transition. The strategy maintains Above Average Process and People ratings and a Silver Morningstar Analyst Rating, reflecting confidence in its continued success despite the managerial change.

title: Investors Push Home Depot and Omnicom to Steer Ads From Misinformation (Published 2021)
summary: Shareholders in Home Depot and Omnicom have filed resolutions urging the companies to investigate whether their advertising spending contributes to the spread of hate speech and misinformation. Coordinated by Open MIC, the resolutions highlight concerns that ad dollars inadvertently finance harmful online content. This comes in the wake of the U.S. Capitol siege, which was fueled by debunked conspiracy theories about election fraud spread through online platforms.

title: Ad-Tech Company AdTheorent Reaches $1 Billion SPAC Deal to Go Public
summary: Ad-Tech Company AdTheorent is nearing a SPAC deal valued at approximately $1 billion to go public. The firm, which uses machine learning to optimize advertising campaigns without relying on sensitive personal data, joins other digital advertising companies in leveraging SPACs for public listing. This move allows AdTheorent to bypass the traditional IPO process.

title: Tim Cook's Response to Facebook's Attack Is the Best Example of Emotional Intelligence I've Ever Seen
summary: This article praises Tim Cook's response to Facebook's public attack on Apple's privacy changes in iOS 14, highlighting it as an exemplary demonstration of emotional intelligence. Cook's concise and measured 47-word statement effectively clarified Apple's position without engaging in emotional or argumentative language, contrasting sharply with Facebook's extensive advertising campaign. The author argues that Cook's approach serves as a perfect model for leaders facing public criticism.

title: Social Commerce Market 2020-2024- Featuring Alibaba Group Holding Ltd., Etsy Inc., Facebook Inc., Among Others to Contribute for the Market Growth
summary: Technavio has released a new market research report forecasting the social commerce market to grow by USD 2051.49 billion between 2020-2024, at a CAGR of almost 31%. The growth is driven by the increasing use of social media advertising and technological advancements. The report provides a comprehensive analysis including market size, forecast, trends, and vendor analysis featuring companies like Alibaba, Etsy, and Facebook.

title: Digital Ad Spending Poised for Exceptional Growth
summary: Digital ad spending is expected to see strong growth in 2021 and beyond due to increased online consumer activity during COVID-19. While major digital ad players like Snap, Pinterest, Twitter, and Spotify are considered overvalued, Facebook and Alphabet are viewed as reasonably valued and well-positioned to benefit from this trend. The shift towards e-commerce and increased time spent online has accelerated advertisers' move to digital channels, with direct-response ads providing a stable option during economic uncertainty, though brand marketing remains crucial for long-term customer value.

title: The dark reality behind Slack’s billion-dollar sale to Salesforce
summary: The article discusses Slack's acquisition by Salesforce for $27.7 billion, framing it as a "defensive" move rather than a success story.
