It argues that Slack, despite its innovative product, was unable to compete against Microsoft's bundling of Teams, highlighting a broader issue of tech giants stifling smaller innovators through monopolistic practices. The author suggests that this trend threatens consumer choice and calls for a rebalancing of the playing field against unchecked corporate power.

title: The Value of Data in a Digital World
summary: This article discusses the increasing value of data in a digital world, contrasting it with the historical valuation of companies based on tangible assets. It explores why data should be considered an asset, despite current accounting rules, and proposes three approaches for data valuation: market-based, cost-based, and cash flow-based, providing examples for each. The article also touches on how data-rich enterprises can seize opportunities and mentions related ETFs that invest in data-centric technologies.

title: 115 Amazon lobbyists. 1 works on climate
summary: Despite Amazon's public stance on climate action and its "Climate Pledge," an analysis reveals that only one out of its 115 lobbyists is focused on environmental issues. This raises questions about the company's commitment, with critics suggesting it may be "greenwashing." Other tech giants like Facebook also show similar discrepancies, while Microsoft, Apple, and Google appear to align their lobbying efforts more closely with their climate concerns.

title: FAANG stands for five very successful tech companies that can move the stock market — here's what to know about investing in them
summary: The article defines FAANG as an acronym representing Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix, and Google, five influential tech companies that significantly impact the stock market. It details their historical performance, their combined market capitalization, and how investors can invest in them, either individually or through various tech and index funds. The piece emphasizes their role as modern-day blue-chip stocks and their substantial impact on the S&P 500 and the broader US economy.

title: Visa's Pursuit of Plaid Looks Too Much Like Facebook-Instagram
summary: The Department of Justice filed a lawsuit to block Visa's $5.3 billion acquisition of Plaid, arguing it eliminates a competitive threat in the payments market. Regulators are learning from past mistakes with Big Tech, such as Facebook's acquisition of Instagram, and are now taking a longer-term view on potential market impact. The article suggests Visa's attempt to acquire Plaid mirrors Facebook's acquisition of Instagram, highlighting how an established giant aims to absorb an emerging competitor.

title: A Look Behind the Vimeo Brand
summary: This article explores Vimeo's unique position in the crowded video platform market, highlighting its focus on community, storytelling tools, and value proposition compared to competitors like YouTube. Author Bryan Elliott shares insights from his professional experience and an interview with Vimeo CMO Harris Beber, discussing Vimeo's features, OTT capabilities, and a new service connecting creators with video professionals. The piece also delves into the author's personal journey in content creation, including his early experiences in the entertainment industry and the inspiration behind his career path, concluding that now is an optimal time for video storytelling.

title: ARK Invest's Cathie Wood Reveals Her Successful Playbook
summary: Cathie Wood, founder and CEO of ARK Invest, shares her "playbook" for success, emphasizing thinking big, focusing on innovation, and embracing disruption. Her firm's impressive growth and the performance of its ARK Innovation ETF (ARKK) demonstrate the effectiveness of her approach, which includes conviction in ideas, continuous brainstorming, curiosity, and collaboration with innovators. Wood also highlights the importance of making your own opportunities and the value of mentorship.

title: Facebook, Google and Microsoft 'avoiding $3bn in tax in poorer nations'
summary: ActionAid estimates that Google, Facebook, and Microsoft are avoiding up to $2.8bn (£2.2bn) in tax revenue in developing nations, a sum that could significantly boost public services like healthcare and education. The charity is advocating for a new global tax system, ideally under the United Nations, requiring large corporations to pay a minimum tax rate based on their "real economic presence." This initiative highlights long-standing concerns about tech giants' tax contributions and their impact on global south countries, especially as these companies have seen soaring revenues during the pandemic.

title: How to invest in the S&P 500 without betting hard on the ‘FAAMG’ stocks that are 20% of the index
summary: This article discusses how to invest in the S&P 500 without heavily relying on the "FAAMG" stocks (Facebook, Apple, Amazon.com, Microsoft, and Google/Alphabet), which represent a significant portion of the index's valuation. It suggests that when investing in a standard S&P 500 index fund, one is implicitly making a large bet on the continued success of these five tech giants. The article hints at an alternative strategy, specifically mentioning an "Equal-weight S&P 500 ETF," for investors looking to diversify away from the concentrated influence of FAAMG stocks within the S&P 500.

title: Facebook’s dating service goes live in Europe after long delay
summary: Facebook Inc. has launched its dating service in Europe after months of delays due to data protection concerns from local regulators, specifically the Irish Data Protection Commission. The opt-in service allows users to find romantic partners, excluding existing friends, and includes a "Virtual Dates" section for video chats. This expansion brings significant competition to existing dating market leaders like Bumble, Badoo, Tinder, and OkCupid, amidst a resurgence of social-distancing rules in Europe.

title: Augmented Reality (AR) Market Will Showcase Positive
summary: Technavio predicts that the Augmented Reality (AR) market is poised to grow by USD 76.99 billion during 2020-2024, driven significantly by the adoption of AR-enabled smart glasses. The market is concentrated with major players like Alphabet Inc. and Facebook Inc., and is expected to decelerate in concentration over the forecast period. The report highlights the increasing popularity of AR in smartphones and tablets as a key growth driver, offering detailed market analysis and segmentation.

title: To Fight Apple and Google, Smaller App Rivals Organize a Coalition (Published 2020)
summary: Smaller app developers like Spotify, Match Group, and Epic Games have formed the "Coalition for App Fairness" to challenge the dominance and app store practices of Apple and Google. This move comes as scrutiny intensifies on major tech companies for alleged antitrust violations. The coalition aims to advocate for changes in app store policies and "protect the app economy."

title: Qualcomm’s Snapdragon XR2 Platform powering the Oculus Quest 2
summary: Qualcomm announced that its Snapdragon XR2 Platform powers the new Oculus Quest 2 VR headset, a result of years of collaboration with Facebook. The platform significantly enhances performance over its predecessor, offering improved CPU/GPU, higher resolution display, advanced AI processing, and Wi-Fi 6 connectivity for an immersive VR experience. Both companies highlight the platform's role in advancing VR technology for gaming, fitness, entertainment, and business applications.

title: What to Expect with the Release of Apple iOS14
summary: Apple's iOS14 update introduces significant privacy changes, requiring consumer opt-in for sharing personal data with third-party apps for ad targeting, primarily affecting the use of the IDFA. This shift presents challenges for app advertisers and platforms like Outbrain, which are adapting by participating in Apple’s SKAdNetwork framework, working with Mobile Measurement Partners, and leveraging their extensive network on the open web. The changes are expected to have a massive impact on in-app advertising, particularly for social platforms like Facebook, making it crucial for advertisers to diversify their media mix.

title: Publishers are getting a (brief) reprieve from Apple’s coming ad-pocalypse
summary: Apple has delayed a planned privacy change for iOS 14, requiring explicit user permission for ad tracking, until early 2021. This move provides a temporary reprieve for publishers and developers who rely on ad revenue, giving them more time to adapt. While larger publishers like The New York Times are better equipped to handle these changes with their own data stacks, smaller entities will face greater challenges and may resort to tighter registration walls.

title: Apple delays iPhone change that's expected to make it harder for Facebook and other apps to target ads
summary: Apple announced a delay until early 2021 for a planned change to the iPhone operating system that would impact how mobile advertisers track users. This privacy-focused update, previously set for iOS 14, gives developers more time to adapt to new rules requiring user permission to track their activity. The change is expected to significantly affect mobile advertising, with Facebook warning of potential revenue drops for publishers.

title: Apple Becomes First U.S. Company Worth More Than $2 Trillion
summary: Apple achieved a new financial milestone, becoming the first publicly traded U.S. company to reach a market capitalization of over $2 trillion. This valuation marks a doubling in just two years, driven by a strong stock performance, especially during the pandemic due to work-from-home trends and robust online sales. The company's market cap now surpasses that of other U.S. tech giants and the GDP of several developed countries, with a four-for-one stock split planned to make shares more accessible.

title: Former PayPal Holdings executive Stephane Kasriel roped in to lead Facebook Pay
summary: Facebook Inc. has brought in former PayPal Holdings Inc. executive Stephane Kasriel to head Facebook Pay. The company will also establish a new group to oversee its various payment initiatives, including Facebook Pay and WhatsApp payments, as part of a move to integrate its apps more closely. Kasriel previously served as the Chief Executive Officer of freelance marketplace Upwork Inc.

title: Antitrust hawks, restaurants want to rein in food delivery apps
summary: An online campaign led by the American Economic Liberties Project is launching to limit the market power of food delivery apps like Grubhub and Uber Eats. The campaign aims to lobby local and state governments to cap fees charged by these apps, which restaurants contend are predatory, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic. Additionally, the campaign seeks Federal Trade Commission investigation into the companies for alleged anti-competitive practices.

title: Zuckerberg was right: Ad boycotts won't hurt Facebook that much
summary: Despite a major advertiser boycott in July 2020 via the "#StopHateForProfit" campaign, Facebook's revenue was largely unaffected, with the company projecting continued ad revenue growth. While many corporations like Coca-Cola, HP, and CVS Health extended their ad pauses, Facebook's diverse advertiser base, primarily small businesses, mitigated the financial impact from larger companies. Mark Zuckerberg had predicted advertisers would return, and several companies did resume spending, though many are continuing to monitor Facebook's efforts to combat hate speech.

title: Tim Cook Says These 3 Words Guide Every Decision at Apple
summary: Tim Cook stated that "privacy, security, and quality" guide every decision at Apple, especially in its app review process. The article argues that these three words differentiate Apple from its competitors, particularly concerning data privacy and product experience. It emphasizes that these principles provide clarity for Apple's decisions and are foundational to its operations, serving as a lesson for other leaders.

title: Here’s what the CEOs of Apple, Amazon, Facebook and Alphabet will say at Wednesday’s antitrust hearing
summary: The CEOs of Apple, Amazon, Facebook, and Alphabet are scheduled to testify before a House antitrust panel on Wednesday. Their prepared statements indicate they will argue that competition exists and their companies strengthen America. The executives, including Jeff Bezos, Tim Cook, Mark Zuckerberg, and Sundar Pichai, will appear via videoconference.

title: Facebook Proposes $650M Privacy Class Action Settlement
summary: A California judge is set to preliminarily approve a revised $650 million Facebook privacy class action settlement. The social media giant increased its initial $550 million offer after concerns that the original amount wouldn't adequately compensate millions of Illinois users affected by the facial data collection lawsuit. Under the new terms, class members could receive $200-$400 each, and Facebook committed to privacy enhancements like defaulting facial recognition to "off."

title: The Trump campaign app is tapping a "gold mine" of data about Americans
summary: The Trump campaign app is collecting a vast amount of data from users, including contact lists and detailed location information, far exceeding the data collected by the Biden campaign app. This data is considered a "gold mine" for targeting voters, especially as the campaign uses it to replace Facebook's disabled data features. The app's developer, Phunware, has the ability to collect data from over a billion mobile devices monthly, raising concerns about privacy and voter surveillance.

title: Uber pledges to double company’s Black leadership by 2025
summary: Uber Technologies Inc. has pledged to double its Black leadership by 2025, joining other tech giants in setting measurable goals for racial and economic justice. The company will also implement anti-bias training, tie executive compensation to diversity metrics, and support Black-owned businesses. This initiative follows the company's 2019 diversity report, which showed Black leaders made up only 3.3% of those with a director title or higher, despite Black employees representing 9.3% of the total U.S. workforce.

title: Gartner: Over 80% of company leaders plan to permit remote work after pandemic
summary: A Gartner survey reveals that over 80% of company leaders intend to allow remote work post-pandemic, with nearly half planning full-time remote options. While most are confident in productivity with a hybrid model, maintaining corporate culture is a significant concern for 30% of respondents. The pandemic has accelerated the adoption of permanent remote and flexible work arrangements across various companies.

title: Google to launch 3 more tech certificates on Coursera
summary: Google is launching three new tech certificates on Coursera in data analytics, project management, and user experience design, costing $49 a month and taking three to six months to complete. These certificates aim to help workers affected by the coronavirus pandemic find jobs, with Google funding 100,000 need-based scholarships and considering completion equivalent to a four-year degree for relevant internal roles. This initiative expands on Google's existing IT support certificate program and includes plans for a hiring consortium, apprenticeships, and integration into high schools and community colleges.

title: Gene Munster Talks WhatsApp, Facebook And Doing 'The Right Thing'
summary: Gene Munster of Loup Ventures discussed Facebook's decision to stop assisting Hong Kong law enforcement with user data sharing through WhatsApp, calling it an attempt to "do the right thing" amidst balancing human rights and commercial interests. He noted that despite potential limitations on WhatsApp, which accounts for less than 5% of Facebook's revenue, the company's stock trades near all-time highs. Munster also highlighted concerns about Facebook's platform content curation and the implications for its status as a publisher, suggesting ongoing headwinds will lead to monetization concerns.

title: Best Buy joins Facebook ad boycott with Adidas, Clorox, others
summary: Best Buy has joined a growing list of major companies, including Adidas and Clorox, in pausing its advertising on Facebook and Instagram for the month of July. This decision aligns with the #StopHateforProfit campaign, launched by civil rights groups, which calls out Facebook for its perceived failure to adequately address hate speech on its platforms. The boycott has led to a noticeable drop in Facebook's stock shares, reflecting the financial impact of companies pulling their ads.

title: Canadian companies Lululemon, MEC and Arc'teryx join Facebook ad boycott
summary: Lululemon Athletica, Mountain Equipment Co-op (MEC), and Arc'teryx have joined a growing list of international brands boycotting Facebook advertising in July due to the platform's handling of hateful content. This move, part of the #StopHateForProfit campaign, highlights concerns about misinformation, racism, and calls for violence on Facebook, prompting calls for stronger content moderation policies. The boycott has already impacted Facebook financially, with its stock dropping and billions erased from its market value and founder Mark Zuckerberg's net worth.

title: Starbucks to pause advertising across social media to help stop hate speech
summary: Starbucks announced it will pause advertising on all social media platforms to help stop the spread of hate speech, following a growing movement to boycott social networks, particularly Facebook. While not explicitly naming Facebook, the move aligns with increasing pressure from civil rights organizations on platforms to adopt stricter policies against hateful content. Starbucks clarified it is not joining the "Stop Hate For Profit" boycott campaign but is undertaking its own review.

title: Pepsi quietly joining Facebook ad boycott: sources
summary: PepsiCo is secretly joining a growing boycott of Facebook ads due to the social media platform's handling of hate speech. The "global boycott" by the food and beverage giant, which spends billions annually on advertising, will run through July and August, significantly impacting Facebook's bottom line. This move comes as other major companies and advocacy groups pressure Facebook to better police its content after the death of George Floyd.

title: LATEST TECH NEWS: Verizon joins others to boycott Facebook. 4 other things and a trivia you need to know today, June 26, 2020
summary: This article covers five key tech news stories from June 26, 2020, including Verizon joining the boycott against Facebook due to hate speech concerns, Egyptian edtech OTO Courses securing new investment, Waymo and Volvo partnering on electric robotaxis, the opening of applications for the AppsAfrica Innovation Awards 2020, and Amazon's reported acquisition of self-driving startup Zoox for over $1 billion. It also includes a tech trivia question and answer about the beginning of computer engineering.

title: Coca-Cola halts all paid social media advertising for 30 days
summary: Coca-Cola is pausing all paid social media advertising globally for at least 30 days, citing a need to reassess policies and demanding greater accountability from its social media partners regarding racism and misinformation. This move follows similar announcements from other major brands like Hershey's, Verizon, and Unilever, amid a broader boycott targeting platforms like Facebook over their content moderation practices. Facebook has responded by outlining its efforts to combat hate speech and misinformation while acknowledging the need for further work.

title: Hershey Is Latest Advertiser to Boycott Facebook in #StopHateForProfit
summary: The Hershey Co. announced it will halt US advertising on Facebook and Instagram in July and reduce its spending on the platform by one-third for the remainder of the year. This decision joins other companies in the #StopHateForProfit effort, protesting hate speech and divisive content on Facebook. Hershey's CMO, Jill Baskin, stated the company is dissatisfied with Facebook's response to concerns about managing violent and divisive speech.

title: Coca-Cola pauses advertising on all social media platforms globally
summary: Coca-Cola announced it would pause advertising on all social media platforms globally for at least 30 days to reassess its policies and demand greater accountability from its partners. This decision comes amidst a growing advertiser boycott, #StopHateForProfit, against platforms like Facebook and Instagram over their handling of hate speech and misinformation. Other major companies, including Unilever, Levi's, Dockers, and Hershey's, have also announced similar advertising pauses or spending cuts.

title: CEO of Gannett's operating company, Paul Bascobert, will leave company; Mike Reed assumes responsibilities
summary: Paul Bascobert, CEO of Gannett Co.'s operating company, is departing after his position was eliminated to streamline operations; Michael Reed, chairman and CEO of the overall public entity, will assume his responsibilities. Bascobert's departure is not due to any inappropriate action or business deterioration. The move comes as Gannett navigates significant financial pressures and a challenging media landscape, with plans to cut $300 million in annual costs.

title: Chipotle Expands Digital Platform With Canadian App Launch And U.S. Ordering Enhancements
summary: Chipotle Mexican Grill announced significant expansions to its digital platform, including the launch of a dedicated Chipotle app in Canada to enhance guest experience and support future growth. In the U.S., the company introduced new ordering capabilities such as Pepper, a Concierge Bot on Facebook Messenger, and a group ordering feature. Chipotle also added a donation option through its app and website, allowing customers to round up their bills for charitable causes starting with the National Urban League.

title: The Netflix of China skyrockets 38% after Tencent eyes potential investment, report says
summary: Shares of iQIYI, often called the "Netflix of China," surged 38% after a Reuters report indicated that Tencent is considering a significant investment in the company. Tencent aims to become the largest investor in iQIYI to reduce competition and lower costs in the booming video streaming market amid the coronavirus pandemic. Talks are reportedly in early stages between Tencent and Baidu, iQIYI's current majority shareholder.

title: General Electric’s exit from lighting business is a warning to other players in the sector
summary: General Electric has sold its lighting division to Savant for $250 million, marking the end of its nearly 130-year involvement in the lighting industry. This exit is attributed to GE's failure to prioritize LED research and adapt to the commoditization of LED technology and the rise of Chinese manufacturers. The article suggests that other lighting companies must learn from GE's mistakes and invest in innovative LED applications beyond general illumination to avoid a similar fate.

title: National Grid Partners Announces New Investments in Two Security Leaders
summary: National Grid Partners announced new investments in two leading online security companies, 1touch.io and RiskIQ, to enhance data security and combat cyber threats. The investments, totaling $14 million and $15 million respectively, highlight National Grid's commitment to delivering a safer energy future. These security solutions are particularly relevant given the increased remote work during the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Saudi Sovereign-Wealth Fund Buys Stakes in Facebook, Boeing, Cisco Systems
summary: Saudi Arabia's $300 billion Public Investment Fund has acquired minority stakes in major American corporations, including Facebook, Walt Disney Co., Marriott International Inc., and Cisco Systems Inc. This move is part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's strategy to diversify Saudi Arabia’s economy beyond hydrocarbons. The fund also invested in financial stocks such as Citigroup and Bank of America, capitalizing on the financial fallout from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Social Media Moves to New Era of Growth
summary: Social media platforms are entering a new era of growth, shifting focus from user acquisition to maximizing revenue per user through targeted advertising and innovative technologies. New avenues like social commerce and AR/VR are being explored to diversify revenue streams. This evolution includes in-app purchases, live-streaming commerce, and augmented reality experiences to further engage users and drive monetization.

title: Facebook Names Former Treasury Official to Key Board Role
summary: Facebook Inc. has appointed Robert Kimmitt, a former deputy Treasury secretary, as its lead independent director. This appointment comes amid criticism regarding CEO Mark Zuckerberg's controlling stake in the company due to super-voting shares and concerns over Facebook's handling of user data. The move aims to address governance issues and investor dissatisfaction.

title: Facebook starts fact-checking partnership with Reuters
summary: Facebook Inc. announced a partnership with news agency Reuters to fact-check content across its social media platform and Instagram. This initiative is part of Facebook's efforts to combat fake news, especially ahead of the U.S. presidential elections, following concerns about misinformation campaigns. Reuters will establish a new unit dedicated to fact-checking user-generated content for Facebook's U.S. audience in both English and Spanish.

title: Uber is ready to join the FANG camp, analyst says after earnings
summary: Following its latest earnings report, an analyst suggested that Uber Technologies Inc. is ready to join the ranks of major internet companies like Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, and Google. RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney proposed the acronym FANGU, adding Uber, as the company works towards profitability and leverages its scale. This optimism led to an 8% increase in Uber's stock price on Friday morning.

title: Snap Agrees to $187.5 Million Settlement in Investor Lawsuit
summary: Snapchat's parent company, Snap, has agreed to a $187.5 million settlement in a class-action lawsuit filed by investors who claimed the company understated Instagram's competitive threat before its 2017 IPO. Snap will cover $100 million of the settlement, with the remaining balance covered by insurance. The lawsuit followed an investigation by the US Department of Justice and the Securities and Exchange Commission, which was dropped in late 2019.

title: Facebook Names Dropbox Chief Executive Drew Houston to Board
summary: Drew Houston, CEO of Dropbox Inc. and a friend of Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, has been appointed to Facebook Inc.'s board of directors. Houston co-founded Dropbox in 2007 and has previously sought advice from Zuckerberg on scaling his company. Facebook is reportedly still searching for a lead independent director.

title: Which tech stock is best? Here’s how the ‘big five’ companies stack up as they report earnings
summary: This article examines how the "big five" U.S. tech companies are positioned as they prepare to report their quarterly earnings. It highlights Amazon as the favorite among analysts, while Apple is deemed the "cheapest" despite its recent stock performance. The article sets out to compare some of their key numbers ahead of Apple kicking off the earnings season.

title: Apple eyes 11 Penn Plaza for new office space
summary: Apple is reportedly negotiating to lease approximately 200,000 square feet of office space at 11 Penn Plaza, a building owned by Vornado. This move comes after Apple lost a bid for space in the Farley Building to Facebook and is driven by the iPhone maker's current offices in the Flatiron District being at capacity. The deal could also help Macy's sublease part of its space in the building.

title: A new ad-tech merger takes aim at Google and Facebook's dominance
summary: Public ad tech companies Telaria and Rubicon Project have agreed to merge to create a stronger presence in connected television advertising and offer an alternative to "walled gardens" like Google and Facebook. The stock-for-stock merger aims to form a major independent sell-side ad platform, with Telaria stockholders owning about 47.1% and Rubicon Project stockholders about 52.9% of the combined company. This move comes as Google and Facebook face antitrust scrutiny, allowing the merged entity to target the growing CTV market more effectively.

title: Check Point finds flaw in WhatsApp that could allow group-chat crash
summary: Israeli cybersecurity firm Check Point Software Technologies Ltd. identified and helped fix a vulnerability in WhatsApp that could have allowed a malicious message to crash group chats for all members. Users would need to reinstall the app and delete the problematic group to regain access. WhatsApp has since fixed the flaw in version 2.19.58, and users are advised to update their app.

title: Why Facebook and Google Dropped Out of the Top 10 in Glassdoor’s Best Places to Work List
summary: Big tech companies like Facebook and Google have fallen out of the Top 10 in Glassdoor's annual "best places to work" rankings. This shift comes as both companies face increased criticism and internal employee dissent regarding various issues and executive decisions. HubSpot Inc. took the top spot, while Microsoft Corp. was one of the few big tech companies to improve its ranking.

title: Adobe is buying the Oculus Medium VR sculpting app
summary: Adobe is acquiring Oculus Medium, a virtual reality sculpting app originally developed by Facebook-owned Oculus. The app will remain free for Oculus VR system users, with Adobe planning to add more features and improvements in 2020. This acquisition will complement Adobe's existing 3D tools and allows Oculus to focus on other VR art applications like Quill.

title: Adobe Acquires Facebook’s ‘Oculus Medium’ VR Sculpting Tool
summary: Adobe has acquired Oculus Medium, Facebook's VR sculpting tool, for an undisclosed price. Adobe plans to integrate Medium with its Substance team to develop the next generation of 3D tools, ensuring continuity for existing users and making the tool free for new Oculus Touch activations. This move is seen as a strategic win for Adobe's 3D offerings and allows Facebook to divest from a non-core business while preserving the tool's future.

title: I became part of the alt-right at age 13, thanks to Reddit and Google
summary: An anonymous teenager recounts his brief involvement with the alt-right at age 13, driven by a search for validation on Reddit and influenced by Google's algorithms. He discusses how online platforms contributed to radicalization by feeding him biased content, and his eventual disillusionment after a pro-Trump rally revealed the incoherence of alt-right ideas in person. The author concludes by calling for tech companies to be held accountable for their role in facilitating the spread of destructive ideologies.

title: PayPal just struck L.A.’s biggest ever tech deal
summary: PayPal Holdings Inc. announced the acquisition of Honey Science Corp. for $4 billion, marking the largest tech deal in Los Angeles history. Honey, a popular browser extension for price comparison, will be integrated into PayPal and Venmo to extend consumer engagement beyond checkout. This acquisition is seen as transformative, accelerating PayPal's capabilities and market relevance, especially given Honey's profitability and strong growth.

title: Can All Online Harms Be Tackled Using the Same Regulatory Approach?
summary: This article examines the UK's proposal for regulating online harms and questions whether illegal and lawful harms can be addressed with the same approach. It analyzes four factors (clear legal definitions, tailored technology, known real-world impact, and business consequences) that have proven effective in tackling online child sexual abuse material (CSAM), an illegal harm, and considers their applicability to lawful but harmful content. The author suggests that regulators need to develop clearer definitions, appropriate technologies, evidence bases for real-world impact, and align commercial interests to effectively manage a broader range of online harms.

title: Google starts construction on $600M data center in unlikely burgeoning tech hub of New Albany, Ohio
summary: Google has begun construction on a $600 million data center in New Albany, Ohio, marking its third major tech facility in the area. The project is expected to be completed by early 2021 and follows investments from Facebook and Amazon, turning central Ohio into a data center hub due to significant tax cuts and strong electrical infrastructure. New Albany offered Google a substantial incentive package, including property tax abatement and waived fees, while the state of Ohio also provides sales tax exemptions for data centers.

title: 8 Free Dating Websites In The U.S
summary: This article lists some free dating websites available in the U.S. It discusses the growing online dating market, highlighting that while many services charge fees, there are still free options for those looking for love without a subscription. The author notes that Match Group Inc. (NASDAQ: MTCH) dominates the market, but other companies like Facebook Inc. (NASDAQ:FB) are entering with free services.

title: Mark Zuckerberg Says Facebook Has a ‘Responsibility’ to Pay for High-Quality News
summary: Mark Zuckerberg announced Facebook's new initiative to support journalism and pay publishers, emphasizing the company's responsibility to fund news. This move, launched with News Corp CEO Robert Thomson, introduces "Facebook News" — a curated section of content from approximately 200 partners, including multi-year financial deals and ad revenue sharing. The initiative aims to counter misinformation, promote a diversity of views, and address the internet's disruption of traditional news business models.

title: Billionaire Barry Diller: Facebook is no match for Match.com
summary: Billionaire Barry Diller, chairman and senior executive of IAC and Expedia, expressed skepticism about Facebook's ability to compete with dedicated dating platforms like Match.com. He stated that companies focused solely on dating services tend to perform better than those "dabbling" in the space. Diller highlighted that dating is Match.com's core business, whereas for Facebook, it is a "little side business."

title: IBD Stock Of The Day: ASML Holding Breaks Out To New High
summary: ASML Holding (ASML) broke out to a new high on Thursday from a three-weeks-tight pattern, near a buy point of $252.21. The stock's relative strength line is at a record high, with a Relative Strength rating of 96. This breakout follows previous flat base-on-base and cup-with-handle patterns.

title: Brian Schwartz Obituary (2019) - Walnut Creek, CA - San Francisco Chronicle
PayPal Bails on Facebook-Led Libra Cryptocurrency Dream
summary: PayPal Holdings Inc. has withdrawn from the Libra Association, a significant setback for Facebook Inc.'s ambitious digital currency project. PayPal stated its decision reflects a focus on its existing mission and business priorities, particularly democratizing access to financial services for underserved populations. This move highlights growing challenges for Libra's development amid regulatory scrutiny and partner hesitations.

title: Salesforce Founder Marc Benioff Says 'Facebook Is the New Cigarettes.' Here's Why He Thinks the Government Should Get Involved
summary: Salesforce co-CEO Marc Benioff has publicly stated his belief that Facebook is the "new cigarettes" and should be regulated by the government. He cites numerous issues surrounding Facebook, including data privacy violations, election interference, and its addictive nature, which he argues contributes to mental health problems. Benioff believes that due to Facebook's business model, which relies on maximizing engagement and monetizing personal data, governmental intervention through national privacy laws is necessary as the company cannot regulate itself.

title: The Merged Taboola-Outbrain Wants to Take on Facebook and Google
summary: Taboola and Outbrain have announced a merger agreement aiming to create a stronger alternative to advertising giants Facebook and Google. The combined entity will have over 2000 employees and projected revenues of $2 billion in 2019, with Taboola's CEO Adam Singolda leading the new company. Outbrain shareholders will receive a 30% stake and $250 million in cash.

title: Facebook Boosts New Dating App With Instagram Integration
summary: Facebook is launching its dating feature in the U.S., integrating users' Facebook and Instagram profiles for the first time. This service, which has been tested in 19 other countries since its 2018 unveiling, signifies a deeper connection between Facebook's social platforms. The dating program has expanded to 20 countries, enhancing its reach and interoperability.

title: Why Big Companies Are Thinking Like Startups
summary: Large corporations like JPMorgan Chase are adopting startup methodologies to foster innovation and maintain competitiveness in a rapidly changing market. This involves minimizing waste, maximizing customer value, embracing Agile development, and implementing a "three horizons" framework for innovation, with a focus on continuous customer feedback. These strategies aim to accelerate product development and deliver value faster, much like their smaller, more nimble counterparts.

title: Lyft founders giving more than 1.5 million shares to donor-advised fund
summary: Lyft's co-founders, Logan Green and John Zimmer, are donating over 1.5 million shares to the National Philanthropic Trust, a donor-advised fund. This move involves converting class B shares to class A common stock for the donation, which will still leave them with 44.4% voting control of the company. The article discusses the tax advantages and criticisms surrounding donor-advised funds (DAFs) as a vehicle for charitable giving.

title: News Corp’s Knewz Aggregation Service Aims to Counter Facebook, Google
summary: News Corp is developing "Knewz," a news-aggregation app designed to counter Google and Facebook by presenting content without "bias" and spanning a wide range of sources. The company has long accused tech giants of profiting from its content without compensation and sees Knewz as a way to reward journalism provenance and drive traffic to publishers. Knewz will include content from diverse outlets and direct users to publishers' sites, reportedly without taking a cut of ad revenue.

title: Facebook contractor Genpact doubles minimum salaries for content moderators in India: report
summary: Facebook contractor Genpact has reportedly more than doubled the minimum salaries for new content moderator recruits in India to Rs 250,000 ($3,503) per year, up from Rs 100,000 ($1,401). This increase only applies to new hires and follows earlier reports of underpaid and stressful working conditions. Facebook also increased pay and benefits for contract moderators in the US earlier in the year.

title: Emerson now owes BladeRoom $77.4m for IP theft, as judge adds interest
summary: A federal judge ruled that Emerson owes BladeRoom $77.4 million for conspiring with Facebook to use BladeRoom's trade secrets to build a data center. This amount includes $30 million in compensatory damages, $30 million in exemplary damages, and an additional $17.4 million in interest. Emerson is appealing the judgment, including the interest and attorney fees, while the companies also dispute the amount Emerson will pay for BladeRoom's legal costs.

title: Ex-Corporate Lawyer’s Idea: Rein In ‘Sociopaths’ in the Boardroom (Published 2019)
summary: Jamie Gamble, a retired corporate lawyer from Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, has concluded that corporate executives are "legally obligated to act like sociopaths." He argues that corporations are structured to care only about maximizing their own profits, viewing this as a "textbook case of antisocial personality disorder." Gamble's epiphany, which he developed while working on a novel, led him to write an essay about the "complex network of horribles" in corporate America.

title: Apple Is Now the Most Valuable Brand Ever, Thanks to This 1 Thing. (The Good News Is You Can Totally Do It Too)
summary: Apple has become the most valuable brand globally, valued at $205 billion, largely due to its commitment to delighting customers beyond expectations. While the iPhone's success contributes, the core reason for its brand value lies in fostering positive feelings through every customer interaction. The article suggests that any business can achieve similar brand success by focusing on unexpected customer delight rather than just meeting expectations.

title: Target Nabs Former Facebook Manager Hari Govind
summary: Target Corp. has appointed Hari Govind, formerly a group manager at Facebook, as its senior vice president of infrastructure and operations for its technology team. In this new role, Govind will oversee digital infrastructure and technology across Target's various operations, leveraging his over two decades of experience to enhance the retailer's technological capabilities. This appointment aligns with Target's ongoing strategy to prioritize digital integration and technology in its business model.

title: Big tech company to move HQ from Sunnyvale to San Jose
summary: Rambus Inc. is relocating its headquarters from Sunnyvale to North San Jose, acquiring 90,000 square feet at 4453 North First St. The move is driven by the desire for a more modern workspace, lower lease costs, and proximity to employee housing, reflecting a broader trend of tech companies moving to San Jose as the Peninsula's commercial vacancy rates tighten. This shift highlights San Jose's growing appeal for tech companies, demonstrated by other recent moves like HPE and McAfee, and ongoing development in the area.

title: ETF Flows Report: Communication Services is "Sector to Watch"
summary: A State Street Global Advisors report highlights communication services as a sector to watch due to strong earnings and positive flow momentum, despite a temporary dip in tech inflows. Direxion has introduced leveraged and inverse ETFs (TAWK and MUTE) to provide exposure to the expanded Communication Services Select Sector Index, which now includes major internet and IT players alongside telecom giants. The new sector composition offers a more growth-oriented, cyclical, and global investment opportunity reflecting modern communication methods.

title: Top 10 Websites in the Middle East and Africa
summary: An infographic from Comscore, Inc. details the top 10 websites in the Middle East and Africa based on October 2012 data, with Google, Facebook, and Microsoft leading in unique visitors. Nearly 135 million people used the internet from home or work across the region. Google secured the top spot with almost 122 million unique visitors, reaching 90% of the digital population.

title: Eyal Ofer's Private Investment Portfolio Revealed: Facebook, Uber, WeWork, Airbnb
summary: Ofer Global's tech investment arm, O.G. Tech Partners, announced the appointment of venture capital veteran Ziv Kop as managing partner, signaling an expansion of its activities. Eyal Ofer's private investment portfolio reportedly includes major tech companies like WeWork, Uber, Facebook, Airbnb, and Fiverr. O.G. Tech focuses on early-stage startups, investing between $3 million and $10 million, and has active investments in 12 companies with two successful exits.

title: Outbrain’s Digital Audience Reach Surpasses Facebook, Google & Others in Key Global Markets
summary: Outbrain announced it is the global leader in total digital reach for April, surpassing competitors like Facebook and Google in key markets including the U.S., Spain, Germany, and the UK. The company reported reaching 88% of the total digital population in the U.S. and experienced significant growth across Europe, attributing its success to consumers turning to the open web for discovery experiences. Outbrain highlights its platform as a strong alternative for advertisers seeking to diversify media spend and enhance audience engagement outside the closed web.

title: 3 Charts That Suggest It's Time to Buy Social Media Stocks
summary: This article suggests that it's time to consider buying social media stocks, citing bullish chart patterns for the Global X Social Media Index ETF (SOCL), Facebook, Inc. (FB), and Twitter, Inc. (TWTR). Technical indicators like the golden crossover and breakouts above resistance levels are highlighted as signals for potential uptrends. The author advises traders to adjust watchlists for lucrative risk-to-reward setups in the social media sector.

title: Fluent acquires AdParlor, a social ad specialist previously owned by Adknowledge, for $10M
summary: Fluent, a marketing company, has acquired AdParlor, a social advertising specialist, for $10 million. AdParlor, originally a major Facebook Ads API vendor, was previously owned by AdKnowledge (now V2 Ventures). This acquisition aims to integrate AdParlor's social media advertising expertise across various platforms into Fluent's existing marketing technology stack.

title: General Motors Competes With Google, Facebook Over Israeli Tech Workers, GM Exec Says
summary: General Motors is intensely competing with tech giants like Google, Facebook, and Apple for top engineering talent in Israel, according to Gil Golan, executive director of GM’s Advanced Technology Center in the country. GM's R&D center in Israel has grown significantly and plans further expansion, emphasizing the appeal of working on impactful autonomous vehicle technology. The article also highlights the growing presence of other major automakers like Ford, Renault, Nissan, Daimler AG, and Volkswagen Group in Israel, indicating the country's importance in autonomous vehicle R&D.

title: After the Flood of IPOs? Next Come the Shareholder Lawsuits
summary: The number of IPO-related shareholder lawsuits has doubled since 2013, with companies like Lyft and Eventbrite facing litigation shortly after going public. Experts predict a surge in such lawsuits due to the high number of unprofitable startups with high valuations going public, potentially deterring companies from IPOs. These lawsuits often allege material omissions in IPO documents and are increasingly being filed in state courts, potentially increasing litigation costs.

title: Philip Morris Influencer Tobacco Ads on Social Media Under Fire
summary: Anti-smoking organizations are calling on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and Snapchat to stop influencers from promoting tobacco products, specifically Philip Morris International Inc.'s IQOS device. This comes despite these social media platforms having policies against tobacco advertising, with influencers using a loophole to market these products. Philip Morris maintains that its digital channels are crucial for ending cigarette use.

title: Uber I.P.O. Values Ride-Hailing Giant at $82.4 Billion (Published 2019)
authors: Michael J. de la Merced and Kate Conger
summary: Uber priced its initial public offering at $45 a share, valuing the company at $82.4 billion, which was near the lower end of its expected range. This valuation, while substantial, fell short of earlier forecasts by investors and bankers, raising questions for other "unicorn" tech start-ups preparing to go public. Despite the lower-than-anticipated valuation, the IPO solidifies Uber's position as a major American technology company to go public, trailing only Alibaba and Facebook in market capitalization at their respective IPOs.

title: Five fund buyers reveal their favourite tech ETFs
summary: This article compiles the favorite tech ETFs of five different fund buyers, highlighting various approaches to gaining tech exposure, including robotics and automation, pure-play sector exposure, and broad Nasdaq 100 coverage that includes FAANG stocks. Each fund buyer explains their rationale for choosing particular ETFs, considering factors like methodology, diversification, liquidity, and how well the ETF captures the evolving definition of "tech."

title: Who really controls a tech company once it goes public
summary: This article examines how tech company founders retain control after going public, often through dual-class share structures with "super-voting" shares. It highlights examples like Lyft, Pinterest, and Google, where founders maintain significant voting power despite owning a minority of shares. The piece also discusses institutional investors' pushback against these structures, leading to actions by market indexes and the inclusion of "sunset" provisions in some IPOs.

title: Publicis Buys Alliance Data’s Epsilon for $4.4 Billion in Cash
summary: Publicis Groupe SA is set to acquire Alliance Data Systems Corp.'s digital marketing firm Epsilon for $4.4 billion in cash, marking its largest takeover to date. This move aims to bolster Publicis's presence in the digital marketing sector amid a competitive landscape against tech giants and consulting firms. The acquisition is intended to be fully debt-financed, leading Publicis to suspend its share buyback program.

title: Developers Lean on Joint Ventures to Fund Hyperscale Data Centers
summary: Data center developers are increasingly using joint ventures to fund the construction of hyperscale data centers due to the enormous capital requirements of such projects. This strategy allows even large publicly traded developers like Digital Realty Trust and QTS Realty to partner with institutional investors, who are eager to invest in data centers leased to investment-grade cloud providers. Joint ventures provide a mechanism for developers to access significant capital, monetize existing assets, and reduce reliance on equity markets to fund future growth.

title: Netflix is valued like a tech company, but its CEO just said it was a media company
summary: Netflix CEO Reed Hastings stated that the company is a media company rather than a tech company, primarily due to its significant spending on content. This stance deviates from other major tech firms that prefer to label themselves as "platforms." Hastings' comments came in response to questions about regulating tech companies, potentially allowing Netflix to avoid some scrutiny faced by its peers.

title: Should we be surprised by earnings surprises?
summary: This article examines the persistence of earnings surprises, finding that companies with a history of beats or misses tend to continue surprising in the same direction. It also reveals that market reactions are significantly larger when an earnings surprise breaks a streak, indicating that "true surprises" elicit a stronger response. The authors suggest that historically, expectations about earnings surprises should account for past performance.

title: JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs to lead Pinterest IPO
summary: JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs have been appointed to lead Pinterest's initial public offering. Pinterest, described as a "digital catalog," generated nearly $1 billion in ad revenue last year, signaling its strong financial performance ahead of the IPO. The article also mentions previous executive hirings and related platform analyses.

title: Is Apple Still a ‘forever’ Company? How About Facebook?
summary: This article questions the "forever company" thesis for tech giants like Apple and Facebook, highlighting recent market shifts and challenges. It discusses how Apple's plunging shares due to demand issues in China and Nokia's past trajectory suggest even dominant companies face significant hurdles. The piece also explores the concept of S-curves in technology, suggesting that while current tech giants are strong, a new S-curve, potentially augmented reality or AI, could reset the competitive landscape.

title: Stocks to Watch: Macy’s, McDonald’s, Agilent, CVS, GoPro, Tilray, Stanley Black & Decker, Facebook, Children’s Place
summary: This article lists several companies whose shares are expected to trade actively in Wednesday's session, including Macy's, McDonald's, Agilent, CVS, GoPro, Tilray, Stanley Black & Decker, Facebook, and Children's Place. It highlights Macy's premarket gain due to stronger-than-expected sales growth driven by digital channels and mentions McDonald's U.S. sales patterns. The piece provides key stock movements and brief company updates.

title: Stocks to Watch: Macy’s, McDonald’s, Agilent, CVS, GoPro, Tilray, Stanley Black & Decker, Facebook, Children’s Place
summary: This article highlights several companies whose stocks are expected to be active in Wednesday's trading session. Key mentions include McDonald's, which saw initial sales growth with all-day breakfast but cooled as competitors improved offerings, and Macy's Inc., which reported stronger-than-expected sales growth due to increased digital purchases. The article provides a brief overview of specific stock movements and influencing factors for these companies.

title: Lauder talks on ‘dual’ company structure at University of Delaware
summary: William Lauder, executive chairman of Estee Lauder Companies, discussed the company's "dual class" ownership structure at the University of Delaware, defending its ability to maintain long-term vision despite investor criticism. This structure, which grants controlling shareholders more voting power, allowed the family to retain control while going public. The article also touches on the increasing prevalence of dual-class structures among tech companies like Facebook and their historical presence in companies like DuPont.

title: Digital Data Gives Billboard Owners More Reason to ‘Love a Good Traffic Jam’
summary: Outdoor advertising companies like Lamar Advertising and Clear Channel Outdoor are leveraging digital data from mobile devices to understand driver demographics, dwell time, and shopping habits, turning increased traffic into a valuable opportunity. This data helps them target ads more effectively, even discovering counterintuitive correlations like fast-food customers also frequenting gyms due to lengthy commutes. The growing average commute time in the U.S. creates a captive audience that these companies are now able to analyze and monetize with greater precision.

title: Working in shadows at Google
summary: Google heavily relies on a large contract workforce, known as "TVCs," who now outnumber direct employees. These contractors, despite often doing similar work, lack the benefits and opportunities afforded to full-time staff, leading to feelings of being "second-class citizens" and raising concerns among both contractors and full employees. The reliance on contractors helps Google keep official headcount low and manage costs, but Google distances itself from responsibility for their pay, benefits, and grievances, despite asserting authority on intellectual property matters.

title: Yahoo parent Verizon cuts value of media brands by $4.6bn
summary: Verizon has slashed the collective value of its digital media brands, including Huffington Post, Yahoo, and AOL, by $4.6 billion, reducing Oath's worth to approximately $200 million. This write-down reflects challenging conditions for digital media companies, a stark contrast to their earlier valuations, and signals difficulties for Verizon's ambition to rival Google and Facebook. The struggling valuations of other digital media companies like Vice Media and BuzzFeed are also highlighted, suggesting a trend of consolidation.

title: Watch AI conjure up an entire city from scratch
summary: Nvidia, in collaboration with the University of California, Berkeley, has developed an AI-powered driving simulator that generates entire cities in real-time. This technology, learned from segmented driver camera footage, showcases the potential for AI to automate virtual world creation, providing a rapid prototyping tool for architects and city planners. It also highlights the future where AI graphics could make digital fiction indistinguishable from reality.

title: SEC Apparently Investigating How Anyone Thought The Snap IPO Was A Good Idea
summary: The SEC and Justice Department are investigating Snap Inc. regarding its March 2017 IPO disclosures, specifically concerning competition from Facebook's Instagram. This inquiry follows a shareholder lawsuit alleging Snap misled the public about Instagram's impact on its growth. The stock has dropped significantly since its debut, leading many to question the IPO's initial viability.

title: Airbnb Ends Forced Arbitration for Discrimination and Harassment
summary: Airbnb has announced it will no longer force employees who file sexual harassment and discrimination claims into private arbitration. This move follows similar actions by other tech companies like Google, Facebook, and Uber for sexual harassment cases. Airbnb states it is the first major technology company to remove binding arbitration for discrimination cases as well.

title: ‘This Is Surveillance.’ Apple CEO Tim Cook Slams Tech Rivals Over Data Collection
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook criticized tech rivals like Facebook and Google for their data collection practices, equating them to "surveillance" and prioritizing profits over user privacy. This strong rebuke came at an EU privacy conference, highlighting a growing tension between user privacy and advertising-based business models, especially after recent data breaches at Google and Facebook. Cook also called for federal privacy laws in the U.S. similar to Europe's GDPR.

title: What Is the Russell 1000 Index?
summary: The Russell 1000 Index lists the 1,000 largest U.S. public companies, representing about 92% of the U.S. stock market value. The article explains what stock market indexes are, how the Russell 1000 is created and maintained, and how investors can invest in it through index funds. It also discusses the performance and fee structures of various Russell 1000 ETFs, comparing them to other major indexes like the S&P 500.

title: Groupon to pay IBM $57 million to settle U.S. patent dispute
summary: Groupon agreed to pay IBM $57 million to settle a patent dispute over e-commerce technology. This settlement comes after a jury initially sided with IBM, awarding $83 million in damages. The agreement also includes a long-term patent cross-license, allowing Groupon access to IBM's patent portfolio.

title: ‘We Do Not Support This Conduct.’ PayPal Joins the Growing Number of Sites to Ban InfoWars
summary: PayPal Holdings Inc. has announced it will no longer offer its services to Alex Jones' InfoWars website due to instances of promoting hate and discriminatory intolerance. This decision aligns PayPal with other major tech companies like Apple, Facebook, Google's YouTube, and Twitter, which have also banned Jones from their platforms. InfoWars claims the ban is a "political ploy designed to financially sabotage" them.

title: Tech Redefined: S&P 500 Companies Worth $2.7 Trillion Change Sectors Friday
summary: On Friday, 23 S&P 500 companies with a combined value of $2.7 trillion are being reclassified, largely moving out of the technology sector into a new "communication-services" sector. This major rebalancing, impacting over 10% of the S&P 500's market value, will trigger more than $20 billion in stock trades by ETFs and require significant portfolio adjustments from investors. Companies like Facebook, Twitter, Google, Walt Disney Co., Netflix Inc., and Comcast Corp. are among those making the sector shift, representing the most significant overhaul to the Global Industry Classification Standard since 1999.

title: Glow: A community-driven approach to AI infrastructure
summary: Meta (Facebook) is expanding its hardware ecosystem for machine learning by announcing support for the Glow compiler from partners like Cadence, Esperanto, Intel, Marvell, and Qualcomm Technologies Inc. Glow, an open-source framework, enables rapid design and optimization of new silicon products for AI/ML by leveraging community-driven compiler software. This initiative aims to accelerate inference performance across various hardware platforms and extend hardware acceleration beyond data centers to mobile devices and other industries.

title: Mobile Native Advertising – How to Boost Signups (and Revenue!) for Your Mobile App
summary: This article discusses how mobile native advertising can help boost app signups and revenue. It highlights five key reasons for its effectiveness: combating banner blindness, facilitating user discovery, enabling compelling storytelling, precise audience targeting, and the use of native video ads. The article uses Blinkist as a case study to demonstrate the success of native advertising on the Outbrain platform.

title: This colorful graphic puts the social-media universe in eye-catching perspective
summary: A colorful graphic highlights the extensive reach and influence of social media platforms globally. The article notes that the top four largest social media platforms are based in the U.S. and emphasizes the role of these platforms in communication, entertainment, and social change.

title: Ken Chenault on leadership and success at American Express
summary: This article reflects on Ken Chenault's impactful 37-year career at American Express, including 17 years as CEO, leading the company through significant challenges like 9/11 and the Great Recession. It highlights his approach to leadership, emphasizing empathy and integrity, as well as his groundbreaking role as one of the few African-American Fortune 500 CEOs. The piece also includes tributes from colleagues and Warren Buffett, and touches on his post-retirement ventures in Silicon Valley.

title: Amex Pulls Ads From Australia’s Sky News After Interview With Far-Right Extremist
summary: American Express has withdrawn its advertising from Australia's Sky News channel following an interview broadcast with far-right extremist Blair Cottrell. Sky News, controlled by Rupert Murdoch's News Corp., is taking measures, including suspending the show that aired the interview and restructuring management, after facing widespread criticism and an activist campaign. Other tech platforms like Apple, Facebook, YouTube, and Spotify have also recently cracked down on hate speech by removing content from figures like Alex Jones.

title: Exclusive: Spotify CEO Daniel Ek on Apple, Facebook, Netflix--and the future
summary: Spotify CEO Daniel Ek discusses his vision for the music industry and the challenges he faced in gaining trust. He emphasizes the collaborative nature of innovation at Spotify, downplaying his individual role. The interview provides an intimate look into Ek's perspectives on the company and the broader music business dynamics.

title: Is Apple now too big to fail?
summary: This article discusses Apple Inc. reaching a $1 trillion valuation, highlighting the immense power accumulated by a few tech giants and the lack of scrutiny they face. It draws parallels to the "too big to fail" concept from the banking crisis, arguing that the collapse of these tech companies would have disastrous economic and social consequences. The author urges for greater accountability through legal and economic means.

title: Facebook & The Perils Of Market Cap ETFs
summary: This article discusses the impact of FAANG stocks on market-cap-weighted ETFs, highlighting how their significant movements can disproportionately affect portfolio returns. It explores alternative weighting schemes like equal weighting as a way for passive investors to manage single-stock risk, comparing the performance of ETFs like SPY and RSP. The piece emphasizes the flexibility and diverse choices available within the ETF market for investors to tailor their exposure.

title: Fear the FAANG stocks? Here’s a better S&P 500 index fund for you
summary: This article suggests an alternative S&P 500 index fund for investors concerned about the high concentration of FAANG stocks within the traditional market-cap weighted S&P 500. It highlights that FAANG stocks constitute 14% of the S&P 500's market value, posing a risk exemplified by Facebook's stock decline and Netflix's shares tumbling due to disappointing results. The article proposes an equal-weighted fund as a way to lower these risks for investors.

title: Ad giant IPG bets big on consumer data with $2.3 billion Acxiom deal
summary: Interpublic Group (IPG) is acquiring Acxiom’s Marketing Solutions business unit for $2.3 billion to enhance its data capabilities and reduce reliance on digital ad giants like Facebook and Google. This deal aims to provide IPG agencies with anonymized customer data for more relevant and targeted advertising. The move also signals IPG's strategy to help clients navigate the evolving digital advertising landscape and address concerns around data ethics and privacy in a post-Cambridge Analytica world.

title: A Case for the Internet: Hassell v. Bird
summary: The Supreme Court of California ruled in Yelp's favor in Hassell v. Bird, a case that challenged the rights of online platforms to publish user-generated content freely. This decision supports the First Amendment rights of online publishers and individuals, reaffirming the protections provided by the Communications Decency Act (CDA) against being forced to remove third-party speech. The ruling prevents the indirect sidestepping of CDA immunity through litigation tactics.

title: AT&T to buy online ad exchange firm AppNexus
summary: AT&T Inc. announced its acquisition of online advertisement exchange company AppNexus Inc., less than a month after closing its $85 billion Time Warner Inc. deal. This acquisition aims to expand AT&T's online advertising capabilities to better compete with Alphabet Inc.'s Google and Facebook Inc., allowing them to sell targeted ads for networks like TNT and CNN. The transaction is expected to close in the third quarter of 2018.

title: Is Match Group’s latest acquisition a response to the Facebook dating threat?
summary: Match Group Inc., parent company of Tinder and Match.com, has acquired a majority stake in Hinge, an online dating app focused on serious relationships. This move comes as Facebook Inc. prepares to launch its own dating product, suggesting Match Group is strengthening its position in the dating market. The acquisition adds another millennial-favorite brand to Match Group's portfolio.

title: Apple to Netflix: We see your two Obamas and raise you an Oprah
summary: Apple has signed a multi-year content partnership deal with Oprah Winfrey, marking a significant move for the tech giant's media ambitions. This deal follows similar efforts by other tech companies like Netflix and Facebook to secure top talent and original programming. Oprah will create original content for Apple's upcoming platform while remaining CEO of OWN, showcasing the increasing competition for content among tech companies.

title: KB Securities acquires $140 mn Facebook-leased Dublin building
summary: KB Securities, a South Korean financial institution, has acquired a Dublin building leased by Facebook for $140 million, marking its first property investment in Ireland. The firm plans to resell equity interests in the Beckett building to other South Korean institutional investors and is actively seeking to expand its global commercial property and brokerage business. Helaba provided acquisition financing, and the deal highlights the strength of the Dublin property market.
source: The Korea Economic Daily Global Edition
source_domain: The Korea Economic Daily Global Edition

title: Microsoft is now more valuable than Alphabet — by about $10 billion
summary: Microsoft has surpassed Alphabet in market capitalization, becoming the world's third most valuable company. This shift occurred as Microsoft's market value reached $749 billion compared to Alphabet's $739 billion, largely driven by significant growth in Microsoft's cloud computing business. Microsoft's stock surged 40 percent over the past 12 months, greatly outpacing Alphabet's gains.

title: U-Haul Self-Storage Investor Mark Schoen Named Richest Person in Arizo
summary: Mark V. Shoen, a significant shareholder in U-Haul International Inc.'s parent company AMERCO and owner of a large private self-storage operation, has been named the richest person in Arizona by "Forbes." While Forbes reported his net worth at $3 billion, the Bloomberg Billionaires Index estimated it at $5.58 billion, attributing his wealth to his substantial ownership in AMERCO and control of approximately 47 million square feet of storage space through various brands. This article highlights the discrepancy in reported net worths and details Shoen's extensive self-storage holdings.

title: Inaugural Look at Brazil Display Ad Market Shows Facebook Leading as Top Publisher
summary: A Comscore report from December 2011 indicates that Facebook.com was the top display ad publisher in Brazil, commanding a 17.4% market share with 11 billion impressions. Other significant publishers included Globo, UOL, and Terra – Telefonica, collectively reaching millions of online users in the country's burgeoning display advertising market. This initial look highlights the dominant players and market distribution at the time.

title: Jury Rules Against Emerson in Facebook Data Center Design Lawsuit
summary: A federal jury in San Jose, California, ruled that Emerson Electric unlawfully used BladeRoom Group's proprietary data center design methods for Facebook's first data center in Luleå, Sweden. Emerson was ordered to pay $30 million to BladeRoom for unjust enrichment and lost profits, while Facebook had settled with BladeRoom prior to the verdict. The lawsuit centered on BladeRoom's pre-fabricated modular data center construction techniques, which Facebook had called its own innovation.

title: Facebook Executive Susan Li Brings Innovation, Digital Media, and Finance Experience to Alaska Air Group Board - May 3, 2018
summary: Alaska Air Group announced the election of Susan Li, vice president of finance at Facebook, to its board of directors. Li brings over a decade of experience in innovation, digital media, and finance from Silicon Valley and Morgan Stanley to the board. Her appointment is expected to contribute to Alaska Airlines' focus on customer service and innovation as it integrates Virgin America and expands into the California market.

title: SM Energy Sees RS Rating Rise To 73
summary: SM Energy (SM) experienced an increase in its Relative Strength Rating from 69 to 73 on Tuesday. This rise indicates improved relative price strength, identifying the stock as a potential market leader based on its price action over the past 52 weeks. The Relative Strength Rating is a key metric for investors looking for top-performing stocks.

title: Sunlands Technology Group (STG) Stock Price, News & Analysis
summary: This article provides an in-depth analysis of Sunlands Technology Group (STG) stock, an online education service provider based in China. It covers key financial metrics, company overview, analyst ratings, earnings, short interest, insider ownership, news headlines, and frequently asked questions about its stock performance. The company specializes in K-12, college entrance exam, and professional qualification test preparation through its digital platform.

title: How Pizza Night Can Cost More in Data Than Dollars
summary: This article examines how a seemingly simple activity like ordering pizza can involve sharing a significant amount of personal data with tech companies. The Wall Street Journal reviewed privacy statements from companies like Amazon, Apple, Domino's, Facebook, and Google to illustrate how much information is collected beyond the cost of the meal. The piece highlights a growing awareness of data privacy in light of recent events, prompting users to question what data they are truly giving up.

title: Apple Co-Founder Closing Facebook Account in Privacy Crisis
summary: Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak is closing his Facebook account due to privacy concerns, stating that Facebook profits from user data without sharing those profits. He criticized Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg for not valuing user privacy while securing his own. Wozniak believes Facebook is unlikely to change its policies regarding user data.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: This Austrian Activist Took on Facebook in Europe. He’s Ready to Do It Again
summary: Max Schrems, an Austrian lawyer, is preparing to file a barrage of lawsuits against companies under Europe's new General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which comes into effect on May 25th. Having previously won a case against Facebook that led to stricter data transfer rules, Schrems has founded an organization called noyb and secured significant crowdfunding to target companies that exploit personal data. He plans to focus on high-impact cases to enforce consumer data protection.

title: Reddit and the Struggle to Detoxify the Internet
summary: This article explores the challenges Reddit and other social media platforms face in balancing free speech with controlling harmful content. It details Reddit's evolution from a "bastion for free expression" to a platform grappling with toxicity, highlighting key incidents like the Pizzagate controversy and CEO Steve Huffman's controversial actions. The piece concludes by examining attempts to moderate content, the inherent difficulties in defining hate speech, and the ongoing struggle to create a safe online environment without stifling open dialogue.

title: 3M will pay new mom, dad workers 10 weeks of parental leave
summary: 3M announced a new parental leave policy offering 10 weeks of paid leave and an additional 10 weeks of unpaid leave for new birth or adoptive parents, bringing the total leave to 20 weeks. Biological mothers will also receive 6-8 weeks of disability time off, totaling up to 28 weeks of maternity leave. This policy, which applies to 15,000 workers in Minnesota and 33,000 company-wide, significantly exceeds federal requirements and is part of 3M's investment in its employees' well-being.

title: The Facebook Armageddon
summary: This article discusses Facebook's increasing impact on journalism, highlighting the existential threat it poses through its dominance of digital ad revenue and its problematic influence on content distribution and misinformation. It explores how many media companies struggle to adapt to Facebook's algorithmic changes and the potential future where Facebook could further distance itself from news or even abandon it entirely. The piece emphasizes the challenge for Facebook to evolve beyond its initial "move fast and break things" culture to address its societal impact.

title: Teleoperated Robots: The Industrial Future Using AR and VR
summary: Teleoperated robots, currently used in medical surgeries and military operations, are evolving with Virtual Reality (VR) and Augmented Reality (AR) technologies. MIT's CSAIL has developed a VR-based controller using an Oculus Rift headset, allowing human operators to control robots remotely by seeing through the robot's eyes and having their movements mirrored. This advancement promises to integrate these robots more deeply into industrial applications, enhancing control and interaction.

title: The YouTube and Instagram secret that Google and Facebook don’t want you to know
summary: The article discusses how Alphabet (Google) and Facebook do not disclose the financial performance of YouTube and Instagram, respectively, despite these being immensely popular apps. This lack of transparency contrasts with Microsoft, which reports LinkedIn's revenue. The author suggests that the financial success of YouTube and Instagram is a significant driver for their parent companies, yet their exact contributions remain hidden from investors.

title: How Google engineers helped India deal with 'Good Morning' WhatsApp messages
summary: Google engineers helped Indian smartphone users deal with storage issues caused by "Good Morning" WhatsApp messages by developing the Files Go app. This app uses AI to identify and allow users to delete these image files, which often lead to smartphones freezing up due to limited storage, particularly in India's mobile-first market. The app has seen significant adoption in India, freeing up large amounts of data per user.

title: Outgoing American Express CEO Kenneth Chenault Becomes Facebook’s First Black Board Member
summary: Kenneth Irvine Chenault, the outgoing CEO of American Express, has been appointed as Facebook's first African American board member. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg expressed his admiration for Chenault's expertise in customer service, direct commerce, and brand building. Chenault, who is one of only four African Americans leading a Fortune 500 company, is set to retire from American Express on February 1 after 16 years.

title: Facebook’s first non-white board member is American Express CEO Kenneth Chenault
summary: Facebook has appointed American Express CEO Kenneth Chenault to its board of directors, making him the social network's first non-white board member. Chenault, who retires from American Express on February 1st, will officially join Facebook's board on February 5th. Mark Zuckerberg stated his long-standing efforts to recruit Chenault, highlighting his expertise in customer service, direct commerce, and brand building, as well as his strong social mission.

title: Facebook names former American Express CEO Kenneth Chenault to board of directors
summary: Facebook has appointed Kenneth Chenault, former American Express CEO, to its board of directors, making him the first African-American member. CEO Mark Zuckerberg and COO Sheryl Sandberg highlighted Chenault's expertise in customer service, commerce, and brand building, as well as his commitment to social mission. This appointment comes as Facebook faces scrutiny over diversity in its technical roles and is seen by some as a step toward addressing the issue.

title: American Express CEO Kenneth Chenault will become Facebook’s first black board member
summary: Facebook announced that Kenneth Chenault, the departing CEO of American Express, will join its board of directors, making him the company's first black board member. This move follows criticisms regarding Facebook's lack of diversity on its board and a promise by COO Sheryl Sandberg to appoint an African-American director. Mark Zuckerberg cited Chenault's expertise in customer service, direct commerce, and brand building as key reasons for his recruitment.

title: Kenneth I. Chenault Joins Facebook Board of Directors
summary: Kenneth I. Chenault, CEO of American Express, has been appointed to Facebook's board of directors, effective February 5, 2018. Mark Zuckerberg highlighted Chenault's expertise in customer service, direct commerce, brand building, and social mission. Chenault expressed his enthusiasm to contribute to Facebook's mission of connecting people.

title: Facebook names American Express CEO Kenneth Chenault, first African-American, to all-white board
summary: Facebook has appointed Kenneth Chenault, the former CEO of American Express, to its board of directors, making him the first African-American director on the previously all-white board. This appointment follows years of recruitment efforts by Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg and civil rights leader Jesse Jackson's lobbying for increased diversity within Silicon Valley companies. Chenault's addition is seen as a move to address the striking lack of people of color in executive and board positions in the tech industry and leverage his expertise in customer service, direct commerce, and brand building.

title: These Internet Stocks Are Red Hot
summary: Despite rapid growth in stock price and concerns over inflated valuations, Morgan Stanley analyst Brian Nowak identifies nine hot tech stocks, including Alphabet, Facebook, and Amazon, that are expected to continue their strong performance in 2018 and beyond. The article details growth projections, financial figures, and specific catalysts for each company, emphasizing innovation, market dominance, and strategic investments as key drivers of their continued success in the internet sector.

title: Facebook, Google Aren’t Tech Stocks? What That Means for Investors
summary: Index providers are reclassifying major tech companies like Facebook and Google from the S&P 500's tech sector into a new communications-services group, alongside media giants such as Netflix and Comcast. This change will force funds tracking these sectors to rebalance their portfolios by trading billions of dollars worth of shares. The reclassification signifies a significant shift in how these companies are categorized within the stock market.
